description:
My sister introduced me to this Thai restaurant. One thing I will repeatedly order again and again is their larb phed yang (basically duck larb salad) - I FREAKIN LOVE THIS! Well, maybe salad isn't the best way to describe it. Duck lettuce wraps might be more accurate since the lettuce wraps/cups are served on the side. Another thing that I recently tried is their pad kra prow moo krob (crispy pork belly with crispy rind and basil leaves). I recommend this also - that extra crisp really does it!

Other things that I've tried on their menu include their nuer yang (broiled sirloin beef served with lime juice), pad kee mao, some sort of basil beef dish, and yellow curry. All decent. Pad kee mao was just ok though.

The restaurant is pretty tiny and parking can be difficult as it is in Hayes Valley. There are other locations around the city, but I've only tried this one! I'd love to try other things on their menu the more I come to visit - but my go tos every time will always be the duck larb and crispy pork belly. You MUST try those at least!
author: Sydney C.

description:
Not the best Thai food I've ever had, but the restaurant is beautiful and the service was OK. If you're looking for amazing food, I'd look elsewhere. 

I shared the Kai Pad Khing and the Pad See-Ew with Prawns. They were both OK - somewhat flavorful. The food came out really fast, which was a bit concerning. 

Overall, I wouldn't come back for Thai food in the future.
author: Remy B.

description:
A bit pricier than most Thai places, but the food was incredible.  Firstly, the menu has a wide selection -- much larger than the usual Pad Thai, Pad See Ew, and curries.  There were many dishes I hadn't seen before in other places that I was excited to try out.

I always order the crab roll appetizers, they're so delicious.  Crab meat and pieces of crunchy water chestnut stuffed into tofu and fried to a crispy perfection -- I could honestly just eat those for a meal.  All of the noodle dishes I've had have been great as well.  I especially enjoyed the crispy pork belly in the Lek Tom Yum Haeng.  

As for the rest of the dining experience, it's fine; nothing too special but nothing off about the place.  The staff are friendly and service was at a good pace.  I've come here around brunch and it wasn't too busy, so we didn't have to wait for a table.  

Overall, Lers Ros has really great Thai food and is a great restaurant if you want to venture outside of the typical dishes you usually see at other places.  It's a bit pricier than normal, cheap Thai food, but it's pretty standard for SF pricing.  I recommend!
author: Kelsey P.

description:
Not really sure why this place has 3 stars? Their food was delicious and service was great! 

My friends took my fiance and me here for dinner. The place is small but can seat a good amount of people. 

We got the pad thai, pad see ew, beef satay? (i found a pic of it and its captioned "first beef entree on the menu"), and a chicken curry dish which was probably my favorite! I'm usually not a fan of curry but I was so shocked at how good this was. I wish I remembered the name of that dish. Everything was really good!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
It had been a while since I had Thai food. When Lers Ros popped up as an office lunch option, I decided to it was time. Our delivery order arrived on Friday, August 31st around 12:15pm via Caviar.

*Green Curry: Medium spicy green curry with Thai eggplant, bamboo shoot, red bell peppers, and kaffir lime leaves, Does not include rice, Cannot make mild ($14.95), Chicken (+$1)
*Brown Rice ($2.50)

I asked for my curry extra spicy and it had a significant amount of heat. Almost too spicy for me, but I'd rather have it more than less. The flavor was pretty good, but I like a nice thick curry. I know traditionally Thai curries are thinner, so overall, the consistency of this was fine. It still clung to the rice. I did wish they noted the curry came with carrots as I'm not a huge carrot fan. I ended up digging all the carrots out. Was left with half a plate of discarded sliced carrots as there were a lot of them. The rice was cooked nicely and had a good chew.

Normally, I order a bunch of dishes when having Thai. Since we have a budget to work with on office lunches, I could only have the curry. Maybe if I had other dishes, I would have enjoyed my meal more. But based solely on the curry and rice, everything was just A-OK.
author: Elena N.

description:
Fast and tasty. Order was ready before we arrived! No waiting, and still hot. 
 I had my staple Pad See Eww but wish I had ordered the chicken satay cuz it smelled so good!
author: Jenny W.

description:
Came here for a lunch date with my mom and was able to order a lunch plate and share it with each other. Such a great deal and more than enough food to eat for 2. The lunch plate we got was one of the curry options! It include rice and a side. We chose chicken satay as our side. The rice was very soft and cooked well. Such a delicious entree! I also ordered the Thai iced tea which came out in a large glass so you definitely get a lot of it to drink! 

The ambiance is nice. Not too loud and not too quiet.  There is an option to also eat outside if you would prefer!! As for the restroom, it is set up for only one person at a time. Not that big of a deal though especially when it is not too busy. Definitely would come back and get the curry again.
author: Sophia K.

description: I've eaten here and in their other branches but never rated it so here it goes: Just try one dish or three at a time every visit because it's truly worth it! I just love this place and even travel from Brentwood to SF if I crave for Thai food!
author: Mac F.

description: Nice dinner with friends before going to see the San Francisco Symphony. We had their Som Tom Koong Yang (salad w/prawns), Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (fried pork belly), Kang Keaw Wan (a coconut chicken curry), along with a fragrant (and delicious) brown rice. It was all quite delicious, and you can request the level of how spicy you want it. Fast attentive service once seated. I think they want to turn over tables as soon as you are finished. It's right by the Opera House, Symphony Hall, and the SFJAZZ Center, so between 5:30 to about 7:30 pm, it's packed. A younger crowd and very loud in the restaurant during peak times. Reservations are HIGHLY recommended during that time frame.
author: Norm D.

description:
Appetizers: "Pork on a stick? Yum!"
**** BBQ pork skewers: tender meat, just a tiny bit fatty; well balanced flavors with the barest hint of spicy heat, use the dipping sauce to add more heat; best dish of the night; could have eaten this as my entree and been happy
*** Thai curry puffs with chicken: delicate curry flavor; deep fried but not greasy at all; very mild, no heat whatsoever 
- Crab stuffed tofu skins: light and airy but not in a good way, spongey texture; no crab taste, skip

Entrees: "Their pork belly will soon be in my belly!"
**** Pork belly: best entree and second best dish of the night; meaty and not greasy at all; very mild heat
*** Pad see ew noodles with beef: tender meat; noodles a bit soft for me but acceptable; no heat at all and not too greasy
- Venison: great flavors and good heat but ... meat was tough; didn't care for the tiny "hairs" perhaps from the ginger or galangal, skip
- Catfish: sauce was too similar to the venison, just a bit sweeter; minor differences like fish was fried making the sauce oilier, skip

Dessert: "Just enough room for dessert!"
= Sticky rice with ice cream: just the usual 

Drinks: "Ummm ... typical"
= Thai iced tea was OK
= sodas came in cans so no free refills
= wine list was big enough for variety and small enough to be manageable 

Atmosphere: "eh? Speak up Missy!"
- small, crowded room; tables crammed too close together; very loud despite sound dampening material on the ceiling; difficult to carry on a conversation; not relaxing at all

Service: "Wow, they made eye contact!"
*** very efficient; responsive to every request, but she should have pointed out the venison and catfish had similar sauces; would have changed our order if we had known

Value: "3.5 stars rounded up to 4 stars. Not bad for SF."
**** quality ingredients
*** while not all the dishes were successful, 5 out of 8 were good and 2 out of the 5 were outstanding 
*** reasonable portion sizes, had enough leftovers for 2 light meals
*** with tax & tip, dinner with drinks ended up being $50 pp.
author: Cece E.

description:
Roaming around Hayes Valley after some day drinking and ended up here on a friend's recommendation. It did not disappoint! The place was packed but luckily we didn't have to wait. 
We ordered the sampler platter, pad thai, and a curry. Everything came out within minutes of ordering. The chicken was lightly breaded and crispy. The pad thai wasn't overcooked or over saucy. 
The service wasn't as friendly but they were prompt AF. 

I don't come to Hayes Valley often, but when I do, I'll come eat here again.
author: Jenna T.

description: This food was literally amazing. The amount of spice used as the rich taste of the curry prawn soup was love!!! I love Thai food but this place took the cake. The service was fast and friendly and the recommendations were on point.
author: Endia H.

description: Best and most authentic Thai I've had west of Bangkok. And I've had ALOT of Thai. The only place I know of in the city that has isaan cuisine. Grilled pork shoulder, Northern sausage and Som Tum. Really really good. I'm glad I found it!
author: Lin K.

description:
So this review will not be about the food. You can read the other reviews about that. This review has to do with the fact that the restaurant charged my credit card more than what I put down on the receipt. Not a significant amount more, exactly $1.50. The amount is not important, it is the principal of the matter. 

This is a reminder to ALWAYS write the amount on your customer copy as well as review your CC statement. Especially if you eat at this place.
author: Sasha T.

description: I'm writing this review because I was over charged $43.29 last Saturday.  I was told that I would be reimbursed in the next two days.  At the time I was understanding, mistakes happen.  However after 3 days I had not seen the money.  I called and left a message with someone who told me that the manager would be in touch with me the next day.  So here we are 2 days later with no more information.  I just tried calling over there and the call goes straight to a machine that says the mailbox is full.  THEY ARE OPEN RIGHT NOW.  I wonder if they blocked my number.  The portions were big, the food was ok.  I'm just bummed about my money.  I've read about them overcharging someone else before posting this.  PLEASE BE CAUTIOUS EATING HERE, THEY DO NOT HAVE YOUR BEST INTEREST IN MIND.
author: Max H.

description: Food was OK.  Why do people rave about Lers?  I've had better Thai, and worse.  Nothing was really bad, but there's room for improvement. I might go back if I was in the neighborhood and craving Thai.
author: Rob B.

description: Great Thai food and great location close to the symphony, theaters, and city hall. It's also nice that they take reservations on their website so I don't have to worry about being late to a show. My friend and I shared our meals and both were delicious. I will definitely be coming here again and recommending this place to others.
author: Robyn N.

description:
I bookmarked this place as soon as Ben F. told me about it... and have wondered about it. Finally, after a concert at Davies Hall, I got to try it for myself.

Thank God we remembered to make reservations as we arrived for an early dinner--the dining room was filling rapidly and had a crowd milling around outside by the time we left. 

The wait staff were jabbering to each other in Thai and to the guests in English. Nice. The smells that greeted us promised good food.

The food arrived in rapid succession, and was so good, I failed to capture any photos. Frankly speaking, I am not at all disappointed with this--the flavors, freshness of the ingredients (especially the sea bass), the setting... a.w.e.s.o.m.e!

Lers Ros is everything I adore about authentic Thai cafes delivered in a modern, comfortable, efficient setting. And when you factor in the price point (downtown no less), priceless.
author: Lu-Shien T.

description:
Yay! 

It's good. Near the Davies Symphony Hall (SF Symphony), so it's easy to eat there and then go see a performance. 

From I remember, it's a pretty popular place and I think there can be a line sometimes, but it shouldn't be too bad.

Can't find it on the menu pictures, but when I went, my group got some sort of pork chop appetizer that was AMAZING. Probably the best I've ever had. So good. Can't imagine that they would remove it. 

Would recommend coming here, but not alone because there's so many people you would look so sad
author: Thomas Y.

description:
Local little spot near my apartment. The yellow curry with chicken was phenomenal. Kevin, my boyfriend, didn't think so, but I thought it was a perfect balance of sweet and semi-spicy. We also ordered the pad kee mow with beef. Kevin loved it, but I just thought it was okay. The noodles were good, but the beef tasted weird. It is also very spicy!

No-go on the spring rolls. Do not order those!

Overall, great place for the price, and we will be back in a few months.
author: Nadia H.

description: DUCK NOODLE SOUP - It's my fav and I don't even live in SF. Go here and get it... it will be so worth it
author: Liv W.

description:
This place was really yummy! A friend and I got the lunch special and the pad thai with chicken. 

The pad thai was HUGE would definitely have been enough for both of us. It was really yummy, and not too oily. 

The lunch special is a pretty good deal, but I would not recommend getting the tofu and vegetables with peanut sauce dish. It was really bland and the vegetables seemed barely steamed. The yellow curry on the other hand was a great choice. 

It was really loud in here, which made lunch a bit unpleasant. I would recommend getting takeout from here. 

Price-wise, it was okay considering the portion size, but it is still far from cheap.
author: Amara C.

description:
I had the Lers Ros Special Combination with Grilled Chicken, Sticky Rice, and their Exceptional Papaya Salad.
for Dessert I had Sticky Rice with Durian.
I was so full & happy.
thank you,

(your neighbor who likes to sit at the bar)
author: Rudy H.

description: I had a fabulous dinner with amazing friends last night at Lers Ros. We started out with a Riesling which went very well with dinner. We started with a prawns & mushroom soup and rolls and pork shoulder. Then, came the entries. We shared black pepper prawns and asparagus & Pad See Ew with chicken.  Everything was delicious. The service was good as well.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I came here for lunch on a weekday right before New Year's.  I'm a regular at the 16th St restaurant and had been impressed by the original on Larkin. I love Hayes area so it's great to have a Lers Ros here!

They had a number of lunch specials and the portions looked quite generous. Staff was friendly and this location has a light, airy ambience. 

I ordered the dry Tom yum soup noodles -- which is dry noodles topped with some sort of aromatic seasoning, a variety of pork with different textures (crunchy, soft etc) with lime. I love this dish!  

It was tasty and a nice place to catch up with a friend over lunch.

I felt the the flavors were a little watered down compared to the other two branches, but still good compared to other Thai options in the city.  So, 4* in the overall scheme of things, but knowing the other two are so good, I'd try to go to the other two branches if I'm seeking Thai food. But, no qualms about eating here if I'm hungry and in Hayes.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Decent Thai place. Got the crispy pork and the Tom yum soup. The crispy pork was a bit dry, probably won't order again. But the Tom yum soup was pretty good, came in a large pot. 
Surprisingly they had a lot of "exotic" animals on the menu like alligator. Would be back to try those dishes.
author: Jenny J.

description: The best tasty and affordable Thai restaurant in SanFrancisco. It maintains a good balance of a comfortable environment without breaking your pocket with high bills
author: Oluwunmi A.

description:
I definitely think that this place is better than the one on Larkin Street. And it is because of the location. This is my go to Thai place in Hayes Valley. The line is definitely shorter than most of the restaurant in the area. We loved the Tom Ka soup, really hit the spot. 

I've been here literally one too many times and the only dish that I wouldn't recommend is the blue crab salad (or whatever it is called). They served mango salad with raw blue crab & definitely a picky eater dish. I mean I eat anything & everything but that is the only dish that I cannot tolerate. Haha. 

I definitely recommend: 

+ Tom Ka Soup 
+ Crispy frog legs 
+ Pork Belly 
+ Red Curry 
+ Pad Thai 

Price is very reasonable for the amount of food. ~$18/person (tax & tips) 

The service might be a bit hit or miss but I guess it's like that everywhere.
author: Thao P.

description: Love Lers Ros and have been a customer for years. My favorite thai restaurant in SF. Lots of vegetarian options and amazing curries.
author: Julianna D.

description: I like ​another location more than this one, but the interior design is better.  You should spend time on the ​menu, so much stuff going on, take a deep look at it.
author: Faye L.

description: Don't come here. Staff is the rudest I've ever encountered, their drinks are pure sugar, and their food is overpriced and less than mediocre. If you're looking for Thai food, actually not just Thai food but food in general, this isn't the place to go. I never write reviews but I had never felt so unwelcome before. Would give 0 stars if I could.
author: Alex H.

description:
We picked this place per recommendation and it was short walk from where we were located. We arrived around noon and the lunch crowd was in full effect. Fortunately, there was one table available so we didn't have to wait long. The restaurant had a very modern and urban feeling to it. I definitely enjoyed the vibe here. The waitress took our orders quickly and the food arrived in a timely manner. I ordered the red curry and an ground chicken and basil stir-fry dish lunch special. (around $11 on the menu). The red curry was alittle spicy and I was told the yellow curry a little spicy as well. But overall, everything tasted good and the presentation was nice. Good size portion as well. 

However, here is when it kind of went downhill for me, our whole table wanted water refills but no one ever came back to check on us. We eventually flagged down the waitress for some refills. We forgot to ask for separate checks so we informed the waitress at the end. It was not our intention to create more work for the waitress as we simply forgot. The waitress rolls her eyes and looked SUPER annoyed and scolded us " Next time when you come back tell me in the beginning". It wasn't so much what she said, it's how she said it. This just left a bad taste in my mouth. So probably won't be back..
author: Shannen C.

description:
Picked this place for Team Lunch on Manager's recommendation. Very Fancy thai place with glass exterior and very chic interior. I totally dig places that put in thoughts on the interior and exterior. The place had a very urban modern feel to it, perfect place for a date night. 
No waiting, we got a seated immediately. The server started us with water and menu cards, I scanned and asked my manager for recommendations. He highly recommended the alligator, frog and larb Kai(chicken) salad. I have never tasted alligator or frog before so I picked the larb kai (Chicken) salad. 

Larb Kai (Chicken) Salad - Minced chicken with fresh cilantro steams and leaves tossed in lemony sauce. Truly was a flavor bomb, loved the fresh flavor. The portion size was good too. My manager got the alligator curry with brown rice and I got a chance of trying it. It was fragrant and very well made. I thought it would be rubbery but tasted just like chicken, I would order it next time. :)
author: Simran K.

description:
I've been to the Lers Ros Thai in the Tenderloin and finally made it out to the Hayes Valley location! This location is smaller, but still just as swanky as the original location. Try to beat the lunch rush because it becomes crowded at around 12:15!

I always get the 2 combo lunch special, which is $11. You get to choose two entrees from a long list, and it comes with rice and salad! My favorites so far are the pad makuer tofu and the red curry with chicken. The pad makuer tofu is eggplant and tofu sauteed in a garlic sauce. Any eggplant lovers will definitely enjoy this dish. The red curry with chicken is the sweetest of their curries (green and yellow), and I believe it's the spiciest as well! This is great over rice or even just by the spoonful. :P The red curry is my favorite out of the green, yellow, and red curries Lers Ros serves.

Service is alright but that's probably because I went when they were super busy at lunch time. I will be back! Their pork belly dish looks amazing... I'll try it one day when I deviate from the combo lunch special!
author: Tara A.

description:
Good Thai food. Fast service for lunch goers. Modern looking restaurant, clean but feels a little cold. But that all changes with the beautiful dishes they serve. 
I had the crisp pork belly with vegetables, which was sooo good. Slightly crisp pork belly with equally crisp greens with a little sauce which also had some heat. Good stuff. Co-workers had the Pad Thai and Sauté Chicken with veggies. It must have been good cuz it was clean plates after the meal. Dishwasher would be happy. 
All in all, nice trendy place with good food and service.
author: M I.

description:
What do you do when your bestie becomes a doctor? You celebrate with Thai food of course!

Walking in we were seated incredibly quickly and after making our selections it only seemed like 10 minutes passed until we were served our food. Lightning fast!

The service was spot on and we all enjoyed our meal. I'd gone with Pad Thai and it was fabulous and price wise was spot on at $12 or so for an entree. My biggest complaint would be that the tables are so close together chairs end up back to back with the table behind you. And honestly, that's a pretty small complaint.

We would definitely return. Great experience!
author: Meg T.

description: Great Thai place near Civic Center. It's in the nicer area closer to Hayes valley. Staff is always friendly and food is always fresh. Love their Thai Iced Tea and pad Thai
author: Sahil S.

description: We had lunch here and it was a pleasant experience. They have good lunch options on the menu with great pricing. The service was excellent. Food was delicious. I had the yellow curry and egg plant tofu both were excellent. The place is clean and festive. I liked the music . Location is also excellent. Street parking of course but there were lots of parking spots (mid day week day in SF ) . Would definitely consider coming back. Oh and they have tons of vegetarian options .
author: Al H.

description: Great Thai food in San Francisco's area. Multiple locations. This one is the only one with outdoor seating.
author: Laura S.

description: This was my first Thai restaurant in San Francisco, and I was not disappointed. We had a rather large party of 8 and they were able to accommodate us, and had our food out pretty quickly. My friend and I split the curry dish that the waitress told us was the most mild. I was surprised at how spicy it was, and wondered what we would have gotten if we'd chosen something actually labeled as spicy. I don't mind spicy food so I enjoyed it, but I think my friend would have preferred something milder.
author: Alexis F.

description:
Stay away from any of the bone-in stir-fried dishes if you value a good eating experience and dislike MSG. I made the mistake of ordering something from the daily specials, and boy, I have not had a more terrible meal in a long time.

I'm always astounded by how crowded it is here, but I think they do benefit from a good location. While the more traditional dishes might be better, overall, the food is quite overpriced and far from the best Thai food in the city. I was also a bit concerned with how quickly the food came out of the kitchen, taking no more than 5 minutes from time of order.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Mmmm.

Koh Moo Yang (Thai grilled pork): If meat that hasn't fried could be described as crispy, this would be it. In Cantonese, there's a phrase that describes food as "bouncing off your teeth" and this is it. Wonderfully smoky, slightly salty, and a good balance of fattiness and meat that is tender and fresh.

Chicken satay: A bit on the tough side, but meat has been marinated and is barbecued. Peanut sauce it comes with is fragrant and not peanut-buttery, more Asian style sauce.

Cucumber salad: They put a lot of detail into cutting up the cucumber (pretty designs in the side, attention to detail!) and this has always been refreshing, never old looking.

This spot strongly competes with Tamarind Hall in North Beach for being my fave Thai takeout. Just realized I had pork (Korean style, spicy!) for dinner yesterday too. Maybe I'm starting to become a pork lover as well-- beyond bacon, which I've always loved!
author: Nicole H.

description:
I ordered lunch for some coworker's and I from here through the caviar app today. As I was three or four bites into my Pad Thai, my fork caught what was an inch long metal nail/screw. I instantly lost my appetite and began digging around to see what else could be in my food. I felt extremely bad for my coworker's since they were now paranoid that there could be inedible objects in their food too. I know that these things just happen sometimes, the screw could've came anywhere from the vent hood or oven while the chef was tossing the food in the wok.

So I call the restaurant so they can notify their kitchen staff to be more careful. I ask for the manager, the person who picks up says the manager is not there. So I tell her what had happened, and to notify their kitchen staff to be more careful next time cause I could've bitten into, or even swallowed the sharp screw that could be rusted (Tetanus) or who else knows where it could have been. The lady then apologizes to me and informs me that they are already very careful ... Obviously, not careful enough if I found a screw in my food?

I contacted the Food Safety Department at SF Department of Public Health and am waiting to hear back from them. I have also contacted Caviar to notify them of my experience.

I have never been to the Hayes location but I always visit the Lers Ros on Larkin in TL and have never had a bad experience, their food is great. I also understand that there isn't much the restaurant could do either since the screw was already in my food and accidents like this do happen. It was their lack of comprehension and empathy that lost me as a customer. A simple "Ok, I will let the kitchen staff know to be more aware" was more what I was expecting.

I will not be ordering from here again.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Great spot for a casual or nice dinner, perhaps before seeing a performance at the SF Symphony, like I did.

A few notes about the establishment itself. Its location means that a) parking is pretty much impossible, and b) it gets very crowded very quickly. If possible, avoid driving in. I recommend making a reservation to avoid waiting for a long time in the cramped area in the front. The whole restaurant, actually, is pretty cramped and dense with tables. Despite this, service was good, with wait staff regularly making the rounds, filling waters and checking in with patrons.

On to the food. We shared an appetizer, the Koh Moo Yang, sliced pork shoulder. Very flavorful, and it comes with a delicious sauce.

For entrees, we had the crab Kao Pad (crab fried rice), pork Pad Kra Prow (crumbled pork mixed with house sauce, over rice), and two orders of Pad See Ew (flat noodles in soy sauce), one pork and one beef.

All of the entrees came in larger-than-expected portion sizes. The Pad Kra Prow was my favorite, followed closely by the Pad See Ew. I didn't get a chance to try the Kao Pad. 

Nevertheless, it's hard to go wrong here.

They offer desserts as well, but we were just too full.

It's a shade on the pricier side, but worth it for the quantity and quality of the food you'll get.
author: David Y.

description:
Alrighty. So. I've never written a bad review on yelp (honestly, check my reviews), so due to the severity of circumstance, I just gotta speak up, as when I last ate at this SPECIFIC location, unbelievable things ensued.
Been to this location multiple times, this last time was special. Ordered the Crab Pad Thai. Tasted great, hearty portion. The FOOD wasn't the issue.
 The serving staff is hit or miss, this day it was a miss- from what I could see ( I am also a server). There were 3- two ladies and a gentleman- felt like they got around to things, when they wanted to. No biggie, we're not in the customer service industry or anything, or in Hayes Valley where people do treat their waiters like poop- regardless- hello standards.

Went to use the restroom, put my purse down next to the sink, proceeded to handle business, and mortifyingly watched 2 small MICE run under the door, play tag around the bathroom as I was on the toilet. Both mice ran around and onto my purse. I threw my jacket at them, and within 2-3 minutes, they ran right back out from where they came from. I'm fairly sure they ran into the kitchen, as I heard brooms scrambling  and attempting to hit the adventure 
Mice,followed by yelling. I quickly grabbed my things, washed my hands and exited to tell any serving staff that were around. As soon as I walked out, the kitchen staff started laughing, as I'm sure they understood what had happened and found it entertaining. Tried to tell 2 ladies that were available- they gave me a dirty look, went to the back, came back and said nothing. 
I totally loved the food at this location, but given my experience, I don't think I ever want to come back.
author: Jen M.

description: Nothing exceptional, just your run-of-the-mill Thai in my humble opinion. It's the type of place you'd consider your go-to local spot in the neighborhood for a quick, easy and affordable takeout. Not a spot where folks are lining up outside on a Friday night or traveling from afar to eat at. Pad Thai with Chicken was flavorless (we asked for spicy), the Tom Kha Kai with prawns was too much on the sour side and the Larb Moo was bland. The only dish I would order again is the Kang Karee (red curry), which was actually flavored right and came out spicy as requested.
author: Alex B.

description: Good Thai food horrible customer service. I placed a to-go order for four dishes and they got the order completely wrong. The dishes that were supposed to have normal spice had no spice and the dishes with no spice were Thai spice hot. When I called to complain they said "sorry" and didn't offer any help or suggestions to remedy the situation. We had to throw away two of the dishes because of how spicy they were. Won't be ordering from Lers Ros in the future. Treat your customers with more respect if you want them to come back.
author: Karim I.

description: Came here a few times and every time the service gets worse and worse. Last time we came here, we bought outside drinks inside (didn't even drink tho), went up to our face and told us, NO OUTSIDE DRINKS ALLOWED. Then, we went another time, and we saw TWO tables that had outside drinks and they were drinking it and the waitresses didn't say a word! Today, we went in for lunch, and we tried to ask the waitress to come over for a question. She told us to wait a second in a rude tone because the table behind us also had a question. But the problem is why do we have to wait if we asked first?! Really bad service. Think they should have more proper trainings before they start to serve people again.
author: K. O.

description: Pad Thai was good. Service was really fast so I had no trouble making it to the symphony on time.
author: Atom R.

description:
4.5 stars

No complaints here! Went on a Monday night around 8pm and got a seat for two immediately. My friend is vegetarian and I'm happy to say that there is a whole section for you non-meat eaters. We shared the fried rolls (solid spring rolls--you won't miss the meat) and tom yum soup (a bit less solid without the fish sauce and shrimps and whatnot but still good).

Service was on point the whole time and our waitress was attentive and friendly but not intrusive. 

For an entree I got laab (ground pork) and she got a pad see ew. Both delish. Any place that has laab wins in my book. 

A bit pricey, but solid food all around.
author: Kat T.

description:
Came here because it was one of the only places still open on Friday night. Pad Thai was drenched in sauce. It was fairly difficult to eat. Wouldn't order that again.

Also ordered the Yum Nam Tok, which was actually quite decent (first time ever having that dish, so I don't have a benchmark to compare it to). It did have too much sauce though... the veggies did absorb it over the course of the meal, and as a result were also inedible after a while.
author: Angelo B.

description:
Portion size was big, 3 out of the 4 people at our table took leftovers home. The prices are very good for the portion size. The servers were friendly and food arrived very quickly.
Our table had a yellow curry, fried rice, a meat and rice dish, and tom yum soup. The soup was very spicy, even for someone who has a high spice tolerance. 
Plenty of vegan options at this restaurant, since Thai food generally uses coconut milk instead of dairy. Would come back again!
author: Yuliana H.

description: As much as I am careful to pitch white-washed Asian places, I have to admit that this one is pretty tasty. While it felt strange to not have chopsticks, the food was very tasty and they definitely didn't hold back on the spice. The portions however, were not that large sadly.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
I've been to Lers Ros Thai in TL before which I liked and decided to try this one in Hayes Valley. I booked a table for 20 here a week in advance for an early Friday dinner celebration when they opened, and they were able to fit all of us at one table which I appreciated. They called to confirm our reservation a few hours before our meal. For the small size of the restaurant and the large size of our party, service wasn't very attentive or friendly. 

We had a big group and were sharing dishes. The server recommended a dish we already ordered so we got double of that dish that we didn't finish. We also were brought a dish we cancelled during ordering but they misunderstood us. In the end there were too many dishes served and the total cost for the meal was more than expected. 

As for the food many of the dishes couldn't be made mild and were spicy. I enjoyed the fried rice and stewed pork rice the most because they weren't spicy. But they were skimpy with the ingredients in the curries. All you can taste was how spicy the curry was and not the rest of the ingredients.
author: Diana B.

description:
Yesterday, we were seeking dinner before the San Francisco Opera's "La Boheme", and we wandered around the neighborhood in the vicinity of the Opera House.  Just a block away, we found Lers Ros Thai and decided to try it.  We are glad that we found it. 

We were a party of 4 and arrived at 5:45 pm on a Saturday evening and there was only one inside table left.  We were seated immediately. Shortly thereafter the people waiting for tables in this popular restaurant filled the small area by the door and spilled out to the sidewalk forming a large queue.   Timing is everything; a few minutes later, we would have been part of the queue. 

The service in this restaurant is attentive and sometimes overzealous.  A few times, the staff attempted to clear plates that were almost finished but not yet.  This is likely due to the small size of the tables and the need to make room for other plates. Yet other requests were handled slowly or forgotten.

We started with the Chicken Satay appetizer ($9.95), which is 4 skewers of chicken with a delicious peanut dipping sauce. There are also some very good pickled cumbers on the plate. 

Each of us ordered a different main dish and shared tastes.  None of the dishes included rice; it must be separately requested for an extra $2.00 per person. 

I had the Pra Ram Nuer ($14.95), which was beef over sauteed spinach with a fantastically delicious peanut sauce.  I highly recommend this. 

The Moo Gratiem ($13.95) is pork with garlic.  Did I say garlic?  Not just an ordinary amount of garlic, but a mega amount of garlic.  I am usually of the opinion that you can't overdo on garlic, but this dish approaches (but does not cross) the limit.  If you really love garlic, more garlic, and lots of garlic, then this is the dish for you!  Very tasty and probably the most distinctly flavorful dish we tried, but then we like garlic.

The Kang Phed Yang ($15.96) is very good.  It is red curry with roasted duck. If you like the taste of a good red curry that is very spicy, then this is for you. My son had this dish and he normally enjoys spicy food, but found that he had to order a sweet dessert to calm his mouth after he finished it.  He said that it was delicious (I tasted it and agree with him). 

The last dish was Sweet & Sour Chicken ($13.95) that fortunately was not the typical kind that you see on some Chinese restaurant menus and never order.  It had a thin sauce that had elements of sweetness and sourness at the same time, in balance. I personally thought that it was the weakest in overall flavor compared to the other dishes we ordered, but the person in our party who ordered it did enjoy it. 

For dessert, we began our greatest adventure.  How can dessert be adventurous, you ask?  It is if you try a dessert with Durian!  We ordered one order each of Sticky Rice with Mango ($6.50), Sticky Rice with White Pistachio Ice Cream ($6.50), and Sticky Rice with Durian ($6.50).  The Sticky Rice with Mango and the one with Ice Cream were very delicious and make a nice dessert.  It served well the expected function of calming spicy mouths. 

One of our party had heard of Durian and none of us every tried it. He heard that while Durian did not smell good, that it tasted good.  This was our scientific test of this hypothesis. 

The desert with Durian was served and the first person took a smell and his face contorted into something you see in a horror movie!  Being brave (as we all were in turn), he tasted it. If you thought that his face looked bad from smelling it, tasting it turned it into the portrait of Dorian Grey!  Yet, being a brave scientist, he continued tasting it several times before concluding that it was terrible.    

Then the plate was passed around the table.  When it approached me, its strong pungent foul aroma wafted across the table and assaulted me.  It is one of the worst smells that you can imagine.  Yet being brave, I took a small spoonful of it into my mouth where it immediately went to war with my taste buds. I tried it again to confirm the initial diagnosis. It is horrible!

It is no fault of the restaurant, it is the Durian fruit itself. 

The next person to sample it confirmed the diagnosis of the first two people. 

My son, who was absent from the table during the initial tastings of Durian, returned to the table.  It was now his turn.  He quickly put a spoonful into his mouth fast enough to not smell it, and declared that it was OK!  We were surprised.  Then he took another spoonful more slowly and smelled it on the way into his mouth and it changed his opinion.

So, perhaps it does taste good, but the powerful belligerent smell that it emits overwhelms any desire to eat it!  (or even to have near you). 

If you do a bit of research, you will find that the Durian fruit is banned on public transit in some southeast Asian countries due to the bad smell.  However, it is enjoyed by some people (likely a minority that has malfunctioning olfactory systems!).
author: Mike M.

description:
When we are a group of five and the dish has only four sticks, ie the chicken sautee, one would think they would ask us if we would like an additional stick for a additional cost. So much was a-miss here.

In addition to a Thai-Iced-Tea they offer a wonderful Iced Jasmine Tea for just $2.00 and they are happy to refill it when asked to do so. At $13.95 their Tom Kha Kai/chicken soup, isn't as spicy as it looks. And, it came in a contraption with a flame below to keep it very hot. The chicken was tender yet watery as if it had just been boiled prior to being placed in this wonderful broth with delicious mushrooms. 

At $14.95 we also enjoyed the Sweet and Sour Chicken sautéed not fried with veggies, onion and pineapple. At $11.95 their Kao Pad/veggie rice, was excellent and may have contained more mixed veggie than actual rice. And, finally their $16.95 Kaeng Keaw Wan Talay/Seafoods in a Green Curry wasn't as spicy as the average green curry. And, this location used fish balls rather than fresh/frozen fish.
author: Caesar A.

description: This is probably one of the best Thai restaurants I've been to in the city. The quality of food is good and the prices are great too. I tried the vegetable spring rolls, pad Thai and pad see ew, all of which are great. The noodle dishes were really big and filling. Would definitely come back.
author: Lillian B.

description:
Finally tried this place for lunch recently with 3 colleagues.  
It was crowded as usual - but we were seated in about 5 minutes vs. the "15 min. wait" per the hostess.
However, no server or wait staff came to our table for about 10 minutes. 
So there's your 15 minutes.

The 3 standout dishes were:
Yellow curry chicken
Vegetable curry
Pad see ew

Portions were generous.  Overall - a pretty good lunch.
author: Lewis C.

description:
My favorite thing to get here is usually their Pad Kee Mao/Drunken Noodle! The portion size is usually pretty big, and it can be fairly spicy (if you ask for it! Medium Spicy is manageable). I used to really like their Pad Thai, but lately I've found it slightly blander than other Thai Places I've been (marnee thai, king of noodle thai, etc).

Pad Kee Mao - 3.5/5. I usually get it with Chicken 
Pad Thai - 3/5
Kuay Tiew Look Chin - 3.5/5 - On their menu, it translates to Noodle soup with cooked fresh meat and meatballs - I think of it as a Thai beef noodle soup (with pho-like noodles). The meat can be a little tough sometimes, but great on a cold day. It's also on the saltier side.
Green Curry - 4/5. Most of my friends like the green curry best (just personal preference), but their currys are usually pretty creamy/rich.


Service here is usually pretty good, they'll try to serve you quickly. 

I've also ordered carryout from here alot since I live nearby, and it's pretty convenient, but I feel like their dishes taste better in person!
author: Kristie M.

description: Don't usually write reviews but there is no way this place should be 3.5 stars. It's one of the better Thai restaurants in the city and one of the more affordable restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Zed B.

description:
Bay area has a lot of bomb Thai joints, and I'm sad to say this place wasnt on the wow spectrum for sure. Centual situated on Hayes street, a block west of Vanness, I had a feeling this place wasn't going to be a hole in the wall. The decor is chic, ambiance is nice with a few tables outside allowing patio seating. The prices were a tad steeper than most Thai places I visit but this was downtown SF, so I knew what I was getting into.

Food wise, we had a friend who only eats chicken and veggies due to religious reasons so we were somewhat restricted with our options. We got the the stir fry eggplant, which was pretty good, the coconut Tom yum style soup with chicken, which was aight, and lastly the chili paste chicken dish which was really mediocre with a weird after taste. The Thai iced tea was OK but a tad too sweet for my liking. I'd like to come back again to try the other protein dishes but for now it's a new for me. :/
author: Ivy W.

description:
This is among the worse Thai food I've had. I found the dishes to be simplistic in flavor and texture, and generally just plainly not very tasty. I recall finishing like half my meal (cashew chicken?) and giving up subsequently.

Get a Thai ice tea though, if you happen to find yourself here.
author: John L.

description:
Not a good thai food.   If you know thai food, please don't waste u time here.   This place don't even have a condensed milk to put on top of a stick rice and mango.  
Few thai servers and I saw Mexican in the kitchen :0 . 
Nothing against Mexican , I love then on Mexican restaurant kitchen only ( get it ?)
author: Attention A.

description: Prett good thai food. It's been a while since i've been here.  The place has a good vibe.
author: Michael E.

description: Wondering around in the valley, I studied their menu in the window.  Lunch combo sounded good and at $10.95 for two items with steamed rice and salad, I didn't have much to lose. I ordered the chicken satay and praram as I love Thai peanut sauce.  The sauce in the pra ram was very thin, I prefer a thicker sauce, like the one they serve with the satay.  The satay was average, I liked the sauce.  Service was fair at best, not a friendly bunch.
author: Andrea B.

description: This place is decent. The flavors were good but I thought the food was over-salted. We ordered the Tom Kha soup, a noodle dish, and fried rice. My friend loves this place but I had to drink so much water that I couldn't eat as much of the food as I wanted to. A plus is that this place is actually decently priced, with good portions (so rare in SF).
author: Claire L.

description:
First let me say that I've definitely had my fair share of papaya salads...but WOOOW. Their papaya salad with grilled prawns was hands down the best. The flavors were perfectly balanced and the spice level was perfect for me. It is a spice that builds so be warned! 

For the entree, I tried the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob and I'll probably dream about it till the next time I'm in SF cause it was that good. To top it all off the service was great at both this location & the 16th St. one! Consistency is key and they got it.
author: Joyce C.

description: Great neighborhood Thai place.  Really fresh, nice complex flavors.  We always get the chicken satay, pad see yu, and yellow curry.  the curry is spot on and the serving sizes are legit.  We always have leftovers.  Can be pricey which is why the 4 stars not 5 - but the food is great and comes out fast.
author: Margo B.

description:
Celebrated my fiancee's birthday here the other day. The way that I would put it is that they are A-OK and just about A-OK. I'll explain.

First let's make things clear:
1. Food appears fabulous
2. Location and ambiance is pretty great
3. Service is fast, on-point

So why is this place A-OK and not 4 or 5 stars?

1. The BBQ chicken I was served (Ler Ros Combination special off the Chef's/Specials menu) was kinda dry and stringy like it was several days old. When I was cutting it, it was kinda plain to see that this was reheated. Just because I've been seeing BBQ a lot, kinda felt like it was at least a few days old given the dryness and stringitude

2. The Scallops I was served (Ginger Scallops special off the Chef's/Specials menu) looked like it was 3 scallops cut in half to make 6. You get the idea. I've bought scallops before and they are almost an inch in height. These were obviously sliced in half. Look at the photos, not super prominent even at presentation. 

So back to the official review. Make no doubt, the food looked great and I ate it and enjoyed myself -- so that earns a A-OK review. Was it gourmet? Can't call yourself gourmet serving that chicken to your customers. Was it great value? When I paid like $22 for like 3-4 scallops, I'd say not particularly. (didn't come with rice either, thanks Ler Ros)

Would I go back? Probably not. With Absinthe down the street, I'd prefer to go there. I specifically targeted this place after looking at the pics and was super happy right up until I started seeing what the main entrees actually consisted of. Other competitors around the area I'd give a try rather than come in to Ler Ros again and plate me several day old BBQ chicken and charge me $22 for it. 

Tofu appetizers were awesome though! If I was to come back, I'd specifically order things that were probably made on the spot like chicken skewers. If you could get a deal with the Lunch menu, I would also look at that as an option.
author: Jack T.

description:
Like the Larkin location, this place is so good but has a special place in my heart for making excellent recommendations for drunk food for me and my girlfriends after a few drinks too many. Since then, I've been a regular (sober) customer.

On my regular rotation is the Yum Woo Sen salad (silver noodles, ground pork, peanuts and chili that hat is slightly tangy with lots of umami) and Pad Woon Sen (stir fried noodles with prawn and egg that have the same satisfaction level as Chinese chow mein), and Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob, or pork belly with hella umami.

This is one of the rare menus where I have yet to try anything sub-par.
author: Steph L.

description: I'm a fan! Nice decor, cloth napkins- -won't seat you until your whole party is there though. I ate a chef's special with noodles and fish cake and pork belly and it was pretty good cost around ~17 for the dish plus tip and tax. My prediction is you'll probably spend somewhere around $25 here for a single dish. I also ate some of my friends' stuff and they all tasted great. The yellow curry in particular was very flavorful!
author: Y W.

description: Went there for lunch on a Saturday afternoon.   Place was empty.  Despite that, the service staff felt disengaged, was hanging around talking with themselves behind the bar, and seemed to care less that we came in to eat here instead of the other dozen places to eat on that block.  Ordered the tom kha chicken coconut soup, which was far to salty and very very spicey.  The Taley green curry seafood was bland and overcooked.  The shrimp and scallops were hard like rubber.    The brown rice tasted like plastic beads, and the broiled beef with stirfry veggies was mostly veggy and not so much beef, and I had to smother it with hot red sauce and a side of peanut sauce to give it flavor.   At some point they cleared half the dishes I was still nibbling from before I was completely finished.  I didn't get what the hurry to clear our table was all about since we were the only customers in the place.   The only time they refiled the water was when the waitress returned with my cc to sign.   Overall...  the food not great, service uninthisiastic, and it's only saving grace was that it was clean and not very noisy.  But that may have been cause it was empty.
author: Vlad C.

description: Food is decent, but my coworkers and I have found scraps of meat in our vegetarian dishes on at least four separate occasions. This raises questions about the kitchen's cleanliness. Notably, this has never happened at the Larkin location so I'll go there instead.
author: Nick E.

description: Not much to say, other than the food is good! I didn't have high expectations, but they definitely surpassed them. I had the Kuay Tiew Moo Look Chin Pla (Special house boiled soup with noodle, pork and fish balls) and it was verrry filling and really hit the spot. Depending what you order, prices are reasonable. Service was great, too, and they easily accommodated our table of 10. Food came out pretty quickly despite the restaurant being full during peak dinner time.
author: Kathy L.

description:
I love this place! This is one of the best Thai places I've been to in San Francisco. I've been to one of the other locations in the Tenderloin a few times too and that one is also delicious. I've also been to this location a few times. Between this and Thai Noodle in the East Bay, my Thai food needs are all covered in the Bay Area. Lers Ros is nicer and pricier than Thai Noodle though, which does tasty, large quantities of food. Both are great, but cater to different preferences. 

The last time I came here, we ordered the papaya salad with prawns, fried rice with prawns, and the pad kee mao with chicken (drunken noodles). I've never had a bad dish here, and I really don't think you can go wrong if you like the sweet, sour, salty flavors of Thai food.

The papaya salad is delicious, but if you don't like fish sauce or sour and spicy flavors, you might not like it! I love the melding of the different flavors in this salad, and it's such a fresh and healthy creation. Something that's definitely hard for me to recreate at home! 

The fried rice with prawns is super good if you're feeling less adventurous, it also comes with a salted duck egg which is excellent if you like salted duck eggs like I do. Also, I think pad kee mao is a pretty traditional Thai dish, and this place does it well. All in all, if you want to try the more familiar Thai dishes (pad thai, pad kee mao), Lers Ros makes these really well. However, it would be a shame if you didn't get a little adventurous here and try some of the other dishes. I've never had a bad dish here.
author: Lin Z.

description:
Place is busy busy at primetime, but the food comes out fast & is very good.  They have a deep menu with some unique dishes.

The Kang Keaw Wan (green curry) was spicier than you would find at other Thai restaurants, but I like it.

And, the Kao Mun Kai Tod (crispy chicken) is both crisp & tender.
author: Matt L.

description:
There are a couple of Lers Ros, one in Larkin and one in Hayes. Hayes is definitely the cleaner one, the food is yummy and clean. They're always crowded, so I usually get to go anyways. Friends tend to love the chicken satay, fried tofu, pad see-ew, and fried rice. There is also the thai steamed chicken over rice, but I recommend the fried one.

If you have for to go, make sure you check for utensils, coz they don't always put it there.
author: Kevin L.

description: Very mediocre Thai food. Decided to try this place out because I was craving Thai food and wish I ate at a different Thai restaurant. Seating is extremely limited/tiny at this location so definitely get a reservation beforehand. Even with a reservation we still waited about 20 minutes for our table to open up. I did not make note of what my friends ordered but we split the Thai Curry Puff (5/5) can't really mess this up, and my Pad Thai with Crab meat (3/5). I was looking forward to my Pad Thai because having Crab meat as an option is pretty hard to come by, but overall the dish was just lacking in flavors. I've had so many other great Pad Thai's this was just not worth the money and the wait. It was a huge disappointment. Another thing that I did not like about Lers Ros is that you can not get a single serving of soup... ALL THE SOUPS here are for 2-3 portion sizes... Great for groups if everyone wants soup, terrible if you just want a side order to yourself.
author: Yoona K.

description:
Yummy food, cute location, and friendly staff (for the most part). I've been here a few times and ordered several different dishes, but my favorite by far is the yellow curry. The papaya salad is good as well, and it adds some crunch! 

The only downside to this place is how crowded I can get. The space itself is quite small, and the tables are extremely close together, but there still isn't enough room for everyone! The staff becomes stressed and irritable when it is so crowded- I would definitely recommend getting takeout or coming at a non-peak time. Friday nights are some of the busiest I've seen, but Sunday nights I've been seated quite quickly. They also have some tables outside if it's a nice night. 

I will definitely come back here, as the food is delicious! But I might stick with takeout in the future.
author: Ayushi A.

description: I got the chicken and peanut sauce with spinach to go and it was so good. Their peanut sauce is to die for. It isn't too thick but has a good consistency to it and their chicken isn't sketchy it tastes so good. It is usually packed for lunch but even getting it togo is a good option.
author: Jazlyn H.

description: This place sucks at making pad thai. most bland pad thai I've ever had
author: Angela T.

description:
This is upscale Thai about 2 blocks from where we parked to go to the Symphony. Prices are closer to $15-20 range. Reservations recommended; we were lucky to get seated inside without them because it was only 2 of us and we arrived early, closer to 5pm. 

The Prik King chicken was notable for the housemade chili paste, making the flavors fresher and bolder than what I've had elsewhere. I had a simple chicken with mixed vegetables which was tasty, satisfying, and healthy.

Service was quick. We liked it!
author: Stacy G.

description:
I was truly disappointed.  Had heard so much about this place being authentic ... but in my experience (which includes 9 long trips to Thailand and 15+ yrs cooking Thai food myself) the food was simply ok.  I think this place has gotten quite full of itself and is a  bit overpriced for what it was.  We very much did not appreciate being rushed so much with every course that we felt obligated to let the server take the serving dish before we had finished.  And yes, I know there was a crowd of people waited to be seated and the servers are probably pressured to turn tables over, but at this point  I really cannot comprehend why 30 hipsters were waiting for that table.   It is just not all that of an experience.

I would not return.
author: Carol S.

description: Got the vegetarian pad thai without egg, duck red curry, mango sticky rice, and thai tea! My friend LOVED the duck red curry, perfect spice, flavor, and portion ( doesn't come with rice though), and thought the thai tea was too sweet (she loves to drink plain cold brew though soooo)! The pad thai was good, but too sweet for me, and barely had any tofu. However the portion was good! For the mango sticky rice, we both loved it but found it just a tad too sweet. Overall this location had a nice interior, was clean, food bit too sweet, and competitively priced for SF. Would come again (maybe).
author: Erika W.

description:
This Lers Ros location is always crowded and busy because of its prime Hayes Valley spot. However, it's still the same basic Thai food. Nothing too special to note. 

The wait can be a pain since you'll get the typical vague "just 10 minutes", and they don't bother to take down your name and number to let you escape the packed front area. If you wander away, your table is likely to be given away! 

I usually stick with the noodle dishes like Pad Thai or Pad See Ew. I tried the 5-Spice Duck rice plate recently and was disappointed by the ratio of meat to rice. Very little meat (and fatty at that) with meager sauce (which was very flavorful at least). Fried banana with ice cream is a satisfying dessert.

Overall, only go here if none of the other great restaurants in the area are booked or have too long a wait.
author: Tina W.

description:
Amazing Thai food ...
The Thai iced coffe is awesome 

The satay is very bland 

The Thai curries are good
author: Abhilasha S.

description: I came here impromptu without having read any reviews after Live From Here show at Davies. Attractive decor and lighting. Very prompt, friendly and attentive service at a time that was getting jammed. The chicken satay appetizer was very moist and full of flavor. Terrific, perfectly prepared rockfish special, with my favorite tiny round eggplant and fresh keffir lime and galangal. The prawn and asparagus dish had very nice flavor as well, but the large pieces of nicely still crisp asparagus were difficult to eat.  One other minor ding for having the tables so crowded it was difficult for servers to get by each other and causing me to repeatedly get bumped (I was on a corner).  We thought the pricing was reasonable for the quality and amount of the food and for good service I will return, especially when I'm with another friend who can handle more heat, since our choices were limited by that constraint--and I love some spicy Thai.
author: Nancy E.

description:
BEST PAD SEE EW EVER!! so glad my friend lives walking distance from this second location of Lers Ros

They take RSVPs but we were lucky without one on a Saturday night!
---duck larb: served lettuce wrap style! Yummy crispy pieces but just a tad too citrusy 
---PAD SEE EW with prawns: they noodles were a perfect fresh chewiness, the prawns were cooked just right, and the flavor was bomb! 
---crispy pork belly: not bad but wasn't anything special, reminds me of Chinese crispy pork 

I wish I could have this in LA
author: Jenny S.

description: Shrimp paste fried rice. Pad see ew. Pad Thai. Pork shoulder. Durian sticky rice. Reservations available online. Short wait for food to arrive. Huge menu selection. Thai Singha beer. Attentive staff. It's no surprise I was here 2 nights in a row!
author: Alias A.

description:
So far this is the best Thai catering we're able to get to the office by 12pm.  For corporate catering, time is of the essence!  Other Thai restaurants don't open until 12pm.  Even the other Lers Ros locations don't open until later.  

This location opens by 11:30am and delivers through trycaviar.com.  We got our lunch by 11:50am, with enough time to set up for a 12pm meeting.   

Great quality for Thai Delivery to Soma!   Thanks guys.  Will order from here weekly.
author: Vi Y.

description: I've been to another Ler's Ros in the city which seemed better.  This one seemed a little more fusion with crab rolls and dried beef (both were actually pretty good)  The egg roll wasn't too good.  I had the Lers Ros special of bbq chicken and shrimp papaya salad.  The chicken was on the dry side and the papaya salad was too saucy.
author: Kent H.

description: This place is the best Thai food I've had in SF! The red curry is amazing as well as the fried rolls for an app. Great atmosphere. Highly recommend!
author: Jessica G.

description: Food is ok. But the service is really bad. Don't know why the waiters here never smile, and their attitude were not nice at all. Feels like I owe them money or I didn't pay them tips.
author: Zhi Z.

description: I met a friend for a quick bite here last night and the food and service were top notch - excellent on both accounts.
author: L.M. W.

description: Lunch special is fantastic - for the price of the special, you could have food truck food with bad service and portions, you could have civic center to-go spots with higher prices, or you could sit down on a very pleasantly designed restaurant and get great waited service. I like the red and yellow curry dishes, Thai iced coffee kept me awake for my 3pm meeting... lunch special for 2, iced coffee and tip was like $30, that is great price wise and def quality provided in hayes V
author: John O.

description:
Used to be a loyal patron at this establishment. Service was never exceptional but food was always consistently good. The other night myself and a friend sat ourselves at the bar like we would do at any other establishment that has a bar. Yes, we bypassed the hostess stand for the reason that it's a bar and also because their was no hostess to be found. 

A man that worked for the establishment confronted us after we had sat down and spoke very rudely to us and appeared to be hostile about us bypassing the hostess stand. I honestly, felt like he wanted to brawl with me. Would have been a very bad move for him on several different fronts. 

After this very unprofessional display of hospitality, I will never return to this establishment. Such a shame because the food is actually pretty good.

The way he reacted to us bypassing the hostess stand to seat ourselves at the bar, not to mention when they were slow, was very unprofessional and deserves immediate remedial training. 

Lers Ros just lost two loyal customers that would dine with them on average, once a week. 

#fail #youlose
author: Chris B.

description:
Lers ros is really good but be warned it's super spicy. Their red and green curries are very hot as is their papaya salad. I feel as though their food is solid and authentic but if you're sensitive to heat look elsewhere. 

Their pad see ew is delicious and probably my favorite thing of theirs I've had. For reference I've been between 5 and 10 times.
author: Sam L.

description:
Very close to the JazzCenter, this is a great little Thai place around the corner. We were seated at the bar due to lunch crowd and we placed the order fairly quickly

- the Thai Iced Coffee is great and a must try
- the lunch menu offers you to order to items instead of traditional one. Which is great.
- the only reason I didn't give a five is the order took 30mins and everyone in the restaurant seem to be in a rush.
author: Sid B.

description: I have been going to this place for  years and used Uber eats  for this place also. Never had a problem until tonight. Ordered on Uber at 7:30 expected food to arrive at 8:15, after 8:20 I called to check in order, the host was very rude not only to me but the Uber eats Staff and forcing me to cancel my order. I would never go back into this place and never recommend it again.
author: Nerissa L.

description:
Whelp. That wasn't great. I'd avoided this place following the shutdown for health code violations. I should've stayed away. 
Food is meh. Same with service. Two stars since I don't haven't shat my pants (yet) today.  Will update if bowel status changes.
author: jack p.

description:
Everyone tells me to try this place because it's the best Thai in the city. I headed over to the Hayes location because I was meeting friends up after. No line or wait, we were seated right away. The restaurant is very nice on the inside which I really like. They know how to cater to the SF crowd: neat and clean. They serve wine, beer, and sake. 

The price ranges from $10-$20 a dish and they nicely separate the menu into ingredients(pork,vegetarian,seafood,chef special,etc) however it's really hard to find the dishes you see people write on Yelp because the names are in Thai, so read the line underneath to understand the dish. 

My group ordered fish cakes for the appetizers (my favorite dish of the night), seafood pad kee mao, crispy pork belly with basil leaves, and combination plate which had papaya salad, grilled chicken, sticky rice, and grilled shrimps. The pad kee Mao is okay. I would say Tycoon makes it better. The combination plate is okay - the sticky rice was a little dry. I do have to say the highlight of the night was the pork belly and fish cakes. You make want to order a side of rice to eat with the pork belly. Mmmmmm.

 I would definitely go back again but maybe try the tenderloin location. I hear that they have better food. But I definitely wasn't disappointed with this location, but I can't say I am wow-ed either.
author: Jackie N.

description: Lers Ros Thai is one of the better thai restaurants in the city. I would say this chain is consistently better than osha thai. The atmosphere is not as fancy as osha and prices are about the same to slightly lower, but I would pick lers ros over osha any day.
author: Annie Z.

description:
One of my favorite lunch places if I want to go on a lunch date with either my co worker or my friends on a weekday! 

Absolutely love the weekly combo lunch special, Monday - Friday; 11:00-4:00 pm. For $9.75, you get a choice of two items plus a house salad + steam rice. 

You have a choice of choosing from 16 items on the menu! Gives you plenty to choose from. I usually go for I. Kai Yang (bbq marinated chicken, served with sweet chili sauce) and one of the currys. The currys range from mild (yellow) - spicy (green). Depending on my mood, I switch up my choice of curry. They give relatively good portion size. I always have left overs of half the BBQ chicken to bring home. 

The service is quite fast between the hours of 11-2pm. This Lers Ros Thai location know that those are the peak hours of employees who on their lunch hour and want to get in  and get out fast. 

Beware: never wear a red dress shirt/red top. I made the mistake of wearing a red dress shirt. Some of the customers tried to wave me down when I was trying to get seated. The uniforms for the employees at Lers Ros Thai are red dress shirt/red top and black pants.
author: Kathleen U.

description:
Service I give 1 and food 4 stars.
Service is getting worst. I will never come back to this location. This is the second time I had bad service here. I thought to give it a chance bc I have been coming for years.
I ordered the wrong dish and told our server. All other dishes I asked for mild the dishes were all spicy. I ate it anyways. They kept avoiding our table the wrong dish sat on table for 10 mins. I had to tell the server this is the wrong one I ordered. 
The server told me she can't return it because I have to pay for it. I said no please speak to your manager. She finally brought the right dish and avoided us for the rest of the evening. Ruined our meal. I would have felt bad and gave more tip.
When we asked for our bill she began again to say she had to pay for my mistake. 
I told her in America and in the industry you don't charge a guest if they send a dish back.
You are lucky I kept the other dishes when they were too spicy. 
I will never come back to this location.
author: Alison W.

description:
I don't normally dine solo, but I passed by Lers Ros as I was looking for somewhere quick for lunch, and since it wasn't very busy and happened to be a spot I've been wanting to try, I figured I might as well eat there.

Since I was eating by myself, I didn't get to try much at all, so I can't really vouch for the authenticity (or lack of authenticity) here. I ordered the DUCK LARB and it didn't really bring me back to the food or flavors I had in Thailand. It was still good though and I'd definitely want to come back to try more.

-DUCK LARB / LARB PHED YANG ($11.95) - 4/5
[roast duck, rice powder, chili powder, lime based salad dressing]
On 7x7's list of things to eat. Flavorful! A little tangy, but more on the salty side. The fish sauce was a little overpowering but the wedge of lettuce helped balance that out. I ordered my duck larb spicy (I actually wanted "very spicy" but I guess that's not a thing). Sadly, their spice levels are pretty weak here, which makes me question how authentic the food is. The duck was very tender and flavorful though and there was a decent portion. Definitely fatty pieces, but the tangy, salty fish sauce dressing cut that fattiness.
author: Jessie L.

description: Ate dinner here on Hayes St. location before S.F. symphony. Street outside this locale on Hayes St. is much cleaner & less bums than their Larkin St. location. Tables limited so better make reservations. Service was fast and efficient. Food was tasty and you can ask for less spicy, if needed. Usual Thai entrees and a few exotic entrees not found in typical Thai restaurant. Parking is difficult on the street or easier to park in the symphony garage ($15) on Grove Street.
author: Clifford W.

description:
Green papaya salad is a must! We enjoyed some appetizers and a yellow chicken curry. Portion sizes are ok.
Don't go for the glass noodle salad, there are better options.
author: Florian K.

description:
This place is alright. The location makes it appealing since it is near the War Memorial Opera House and Civic Center. I love Thai food, and had high hopes for this place based on the positive reviews. The sampler platter was not worth the money, and the noodles we had did not taste fresh. I did enjoy the soup my friend ordered, however. That was probably the best thing I tried.

The service was pretty good even though they were busy. They were able to split our check four ways which was nice. They had pretty big menu, but nothing really stuck out to me as really tasty or amazing. If I was in a pinch, I'd probably come back, but very unlikely if I'm craving Thai.
author: Melissa S.

description: Good Thai food place.  I had a decent silver noodle salad. The price was fair, especially for San Francisco, and the customer service was great.
author: Lisa G.

description: My wife and I are visiting San Francisco to see friends. They highly recommended coming to eat here. My friend ordered for takeout, and made the trek to the restaurant. When we got there we realized that they did not make my dish correct. The women just gave me some flakes for spice. Once we made it home we all 4 realized that our food was all made incorrectly the orders that needed to come medium spice came without it and the regular ones came out of this world spicy. We literally struggled to eat the food. My friend called to let the restaurant know and they did not care at all. Honestly this experience sucked. We came to eat great food and now I know for for a fact we will never come backed again nor will we recommend this place to anyone who we know may visit San Fran.
author: E R.

description: Wow first time here at lunch. I had the lunch pick two special. Fried Tofu and chicken and onion with cashews, white rice. Omg the flavors were so fabulous together. The Tofu was cooked to crunchy perfection and LOTS of it. The sauce was like a honey with lime and peanuts and chili flakes I think. Just spicy and sweet enuf! The chicken on the other hand had a wonderful brown sauce with sliced onions, scallion ends, carrot slices and plenty of cashews. Totally delicious!! Bookmarked!
author: Rene D.

description:
I don't think this place should be as highly rated as it is. A lot of MSG gave me a headache. 
Also they never asked if we wanted more water or beer so the service wasn't great.
author: Tee J.

description: Food is boring and bland. Same with the staff. Maybe the Thai Ice Tea is worth mentioning.
author: Miguel A.

description: Rude, horrible service - hung up on me as I was getting a status update on my order. When I called back, said they hung up because "they were too busy." Unacceptable, abysmal service levels. Not OK.
author: Angelo S.

description: Came to have lunch here. I thought the prices seemed good until the food came out because the portions were smaller than I expected. Average thai food nothing special. Part of our rice was rock hard and inedible so that was a bummer, definitely haven't seen that before.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Just as good as their other location in the Tenderloin! The decoration inside is beautiful and classy. I would recommend getting a reservation since they get packed really quickly. Service was okay. They were fast but not the friendliest.

We ordered the fried tofu ($8) that came with delicious sweet chili sauce. The tofu was lightly fried and great to share for the table. The garlic quail ($11) appetizer really stood out to me. Great flavor and nice crispy texture.

I loved the red curry ($13) and yellow curry ($13)! Super flavorful and great serving size. Highly recommend the pad makuer tofu ($11) which had eggplant, tofu, bell peppers, and basil. The sauce was addicting I only wish there had been more eggplant added to the dish. The pad kee mow ($11) was also a big hit with my group. The beef was really tender and the noodles were soft.

Overall great option for Thai food in Hayes Valley!
author: Linda X.

description:
My husband and I enjoyed this restaurant, until we reassessed the day after.

My husband experienced an upset stomach after dinner and the following day after having leftovers.  We believe the reason why is because his dish - Rockfish Cod - from the special menu was off.  The fish was fishy and tasted strange, and not because of the fish sauce, which we cook with all the time.  The fish likely went bad, possibly because the dish is rarely ordered.  

If it was not for the bad fish, we would have liked the restaurant a lot.  We loved the fried vegetable rolls appetizer.  The sausage appetizer was great as well, but difficult to eat with the garnishes.  I enjoyed my red curry with chicken, except that it was a little too spicy.    

If you order the regular dishes, you'll probably be fine.  However, serving bad fish is not acceptable, especially if the dish is more expensive!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Beautiful and modern interior. This is how the best restaurants should look inside. Service was fast and attentive. Food was ordered and food was brought pretty soon after. I got the crispy chicken over fried rice and oh wow I loved it! My friend got the veggie pad see ew. We both had enough leftovers to eat for lunch the next day. Decent prices for basic menu items. They do have some more expensive menu items..so much to choose from on menu. I'd love to come back.
author: Denise C.

description:
Don't waste your money here.Hayse location.
Food is not great.
Go find another Thai restaurant.
Ate here with friends before the women March.
Prawns and asparagus....meh. 
Legs ros special combination plate...papaya salad was good. Chicken....average.Sticky rice..good.

If you decide to eat there...watch out since food is very hot. Ask for 'mild'....or even non spicy.
author: Ari S.

description:
I've been a fan of the Lers Ros on Larkin St. for many years, yet I've only visited the Hayes Valley location a few times.  My friend and I tried a selection of dishes including their chicken larb, a papaya salad, and a whole fried trout with a mango sauce on the side.  All of the food was flavorful, especially the trout which was crispy without being greasy.  

The service was friendly and accommodating; we ended up taking a moderate amount of time to sort through all the wonderful menu choices on display, but our server patiently answered our questions.  I did not feel rushed at all despite us being in the midst of a bustling evening.   One downside was that the seating felt cramped.  It looks like the restaurant decided to place a lot of tables close together, which made getting to your seat feel like a mini obstacle course as you tried to avoid jostling the table near you (and if you want to get an earful of your table's conversation, you were also quite in luck).  Otherwise, this is definitely one of my favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco!
author: Keith H.

description: Ordered pad see ew late last night and now have an AWFUL case of food poisoning. Upon further investigation, the health score here is 71!!! This is a REALLY bad score. Beware.
author: Tessa C.

description: I really miss this restaurant after leaving. If you want to try Thai food,  you must try this one.
author: Boris C.

description: Bursting with flavors! But it can be a bit pricy for the portion given. This place is definitely quality over quantity.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
*This is my first hand experience with this restaurant location. The important point: all three restaurants are guilty of the same mislabeling of food. PERIOD.*

I called this location on another occasion, thinking they would be any different than the Tenderloin Lers Rose sham.
