description: Underwhelmed by the dishes we consumed, the service felt rushed and the plates weren't so flavorful. I'd hoped for more, and yet this Thai restaurant has some fine qualities about it. The restaurant is close to the ballet, the opera house and the civic center, so if you have to have Thai and you're in the area, there is that. The price and the atmosphere are also quite nice, so it could have just been our night for not-so-good in the kitchen and not-so-good on the service. I might give them another try, but not before trying a few other Thai places in the city.
author: Frank G.

description: Legit Thai food cooked and served by Thais.  The interior is newish and they deliver to my hood.  I'm pretty excited to order delivery and zone out in front of the TV after a long day of work.  (3.5 rounded to 4 stars)
author: Darin E.

description: Tried one of the salads with roasted rice powder (which is very crunchy), Kao Mun Kai Tod (Crispy Chicken), Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (Stir Fried Pork Belly), Kao Kha Moo (stewed pork leg) and a few more I don't remember.  All were very tasty.  Service is good for an insanely busy restaurant!  I like that they have unique dishes that I don't see at other Thai restaurants.
author: MT Y.

description: We used to love this place. The last few times we went the service was terrible. Last time we went they forgot one of our dishes and when they finally brought it out it was RAW on the inside. The cook came out and tried to convince us it was just the "fatty" part of fish. This place has gone DOWNHILL in the last year. No surprise that they were just closed for health code violations and cockroach infestation. AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COSTS. Have to find a new fav thai now. Too bad cause their garlic frog dish rocked.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
Lers Ros is a revelation. Best Thai in SF! They even helped me literally save the day for my girlfriend. The wait staff may not have the best English but they more than make up for it in sweetness.

You must get:
Thai Basil Chicken
Red Curry
Duck Curry

Enough said...
author: insipidphishie P.

description:
Almost as good as their first location !

the garlic rice is delicious.
Servers are attentive.

beautiful layout
author: Paul J.

description: Great place for a quick lunch!  The food was really good.  Got the lunch special - yellow chicken curry and minced chicken and loved both dishes.  Even took some home with me so the portions are more than adequate!
author: Sushant M.

description:
lers ros is consistently one of my favorite thai places around--not only as my neighborhood thai restaurant, but overall as well. the menu is pretty extensive, and goes beyond just your standard pad thai and green curry (although they do those well, too).

although almost everything i've had is pretty solid, if you're a first timer, try the duck larb. if you don't do meat, they have a lot of vegetarian options or can easily accommodate with tofu / veggies (i've come here during my "vegetarian" phases and dishes were still delicious!).

take out is relatively quick (they have a bar with a television that you can wait at), and i've also never had to wait super long during busy times. overall, one of my favorite thai restaurants that perfectly blends authenticity, affordability, and atmosphere.
author: stefanie h.

description:
Pros:
- Delivery
- The soup was excellent (except for how spicy it was)

Cons:
- The food destroyed my stomach for about a day and a half. 
- It's very spicy and they don't ask you how spicy you want your food.
author: Captain B.

description: Medium is way too spicy, and the quail entree was more bones than anything else. Maybe I just ordered wrong by severely disappointed. Wine was also meh.
author: Edward H.

description:
Just went today. Its officially (finally) open, and just as superb as their other location! We ordered the Tom Yum, Pad Kee Mow, and Red Curry with Chicken. It was all fantastic. The star of the meals was, surprisingly, the rice. They do something special to it! 

Easily my favorite Thai restaurant in the neighborhood, likely in the city.
author: Rondeep C.

description:
Found this place on the SF Jan 2015 Eater 38 list, so decided to try it last night (Weds).  Was looking for an affordable spot to meet a friend I haven't seen in years.  We went to the Hayes location.  Tables are tightly squeezed and music was hip.  Overall a good spot for the kind of night we wanted to have.  Not too loud, but enough distraction.  Not intimate.  We had a reservation at 6:30pm and it was nearly packed when we walked in.

Food Takeaways:
(1) Kang Keaw Wan - curry: I found this recommended on yelp and it was awesome.  Prepare for the spice.
(2) I thought the beef sirloin (comes in many dishes) is good, not great.
author: Pat K.

description:
A little more expensive than it's TL sister... this place is great spot for a date.  Great decor and good service.
They will accommodate you as spicy as you want... but you gotta be clear if you really want heat.  Say, 'Pet Mak Mak' (very spicy)!
Beef salad was almost as good as some cholera carts I've had in Bangkok.  Tom Yum has perfect broth and taste... could use just a few more veggies.
Gai Pad Krapow is good... not the best
author: Josh K.

description: Actually came back here after fixing the health score. No one wants food poisoning. Food was better the second time around. Service was fast. Gets pretty crowded too. Tried their fried rabbit legs, pad Thai, chef special sea bass - I would skip that one, some noodles and chicken satay for appetizer.
author: J C.

description:
Listen, I love Lers Ros as much as the next reviewer, but I'm raising an eyebrow over this new bougie location in Hayes Valley. 

I had lunch here a few days ago and noticed a few things right off the bat. The ambience is decidedly more Osha-like than the casual and efficient location in the TL. With that, you are paying a few dollars more, and ultimately getting much less food, with slower service. The food and plates might be more nicely arranged, but literally about half the size with some dishes, and quite frankly I'm not impressed. 

Come here if you want a more elevated dining experience in a cute, safer neighborhood... Myself however? Well, you can find me hanging out with the crazies and crackheads on Larkin waiting for a table at the original location. 

Suck it, gentrification!
author: Clarissa S.

description:
The restaurant looks nice and all. Ive had much better thai food elsewhere...almost everywhere else actually.  I ordered their Pad See Ew and it was quite salty. Not my fav =\

I recommend Osha
author: Eugene H.

description:
We have been here a few times. Their food is solid. We particularly enjoy their soup Tom Kha Kai, whole fresh sea bass Tom Yum Pla Kra Pong, and Pad Thai. Their problem (and I tell you it is a big problem) is their service. Their service was never that good to begin with, but it has even gone worse recently.

Our waitress today, from taking the order to delivering the food to busing the table, was borderline rude while we were being nice and polite the entire time. She seriously looked extremely unhappy and did not want to be there. She kept trying to clear our plates when we were clearly still eating, and when she walked into my chair (the space was cramped where I sat), she turned back and half shouted to me "can you move your chair in a little bit?" instead of apologizing to me. My very flat chest was already against the table, where else do you want me to move to!!!

And it's not just our waitress. I felt that their entire waitstaff shared the same vibe. My out of town guests also noticed the poor service and made comments about it. Reviews about their bad service by other yelpers were also true. While we were waiting, there was a guy who told the host he wanted his money back cause he had been waiting for his take-away for an hour. He was really pissed. My friend also noticed that the host was telling everybody, either waiting for food or table, just another minute when it was clearly not!

I have noticed the wait time at this location since it opened has become shorter and shorter. It's probably an indication of this restaurant is going downhill.

Here is my advice. If you are looking for a quick solid thai meal and do not care about the service, then go. However, if you are looking for a pleasant evening out, having a good conversation with your friends, and impressing your out of town guests, then go somewhere else. You will be surprised how bad service (even if the food is good) can really ruin your entire dinner experience.

I have said many times before, running a restaurant is much more than just producing good food. Treating your guests with respect is the very least you got to be able to do. So for me, I will spend my hard earned money somewhere else.
author: Elin K.

description: I like this place. Go order their Tom yum soup! The pot is fancy with flame and stuff to keep it warm after it is on the table. I also enjoy their shrimp paste fried rice a lot. If you are adventurous(or Asian), try their stewed pork leg. The steam chicken with garlic ginger rice is also one of my favorites in their restaurant (although the soup they give you is a little salty). In general, the place offers good food ;)
author: Maggie Z.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place. 

As little as I know about Thai cuisine, I think their food is great! Every dish I had here was flavorful, and I'm a huge fan of the pork belly!!! Super crispy and juicy, it's something to die for, in my opinion. 

But the service is quite bad. Almost every time we've been there it's super full. Well, it's good food, so it's not only me who likes it, I'm ok waiting for it. The thing is, we always have problems with the organization of this place until we actually get a table. 

First time we went there, we asked if we could wait at the bar getting some drinks, and the answer was no, if we sitted at the bar, we would loose our place on the waiting list and we had to eat there. Sorry I just don't know any other place were you are obligated to make this kind of choice. 

Yesterday, as they accept reservations we called to make one to 1 hour later, at 18:00 p.m., and the lady told us that at this time you just walk in. We went there, the place was full, and the waiting was for 45 minutes...

I mean, if you have to endure a challenge every time you want to go there, is it worthy??? I think not...
author: Carla O.

description:
I am a huge fan of Thai food and eat lunch in Hayes Valley often, so I have noticed the lack of Thai restaurants in this area, so I was very much looking forward to Lers Ros opening this location.

I was not disappointed.  We got the last table for four at noon.  After a short delay, we ordered off the lunch specials menu, which allows you to order two dishes with a side of either white or brown rice. I had the Praram Spinach with Tofu and the Red Curry with Chicken.  They served me a small iceberg lettuce salad with a delicious sweet dressing.  It was good, but not enough dressing.  The lunch specials were both perfect.  The portions were generous but not too much.  The Red Curry spicy but just the right amount.  The Thai Iced Tea was huge and well done.  

Service was pleasant and prompt.  We were able to get out of there in just over an hour.  For $13.00 a piece, including tip and tax, we had a fantastic lunch in the heart of Hayes Valley.

The only downside was it was a bit noisy as it was so crowded, so don't expect to have a quiet conversation.  

I look forward to making Lers Ros a regular spot.  I cannot wait to try the rest of the menu!
author: Frank B.

description: Everyone had talked this place up, I would have rather gone to McDonalds. Im giving a 1 star because the service was horrible not to mention I received my food with a Hair in it.. Eat at your own risk!!!!!
author: Aaron J.

description:
Lers Ros' food is great, and I am excited they chose my neighborhood for their second location. During my visit last night, the food was consistent with the other location, and the service was fast (almost too fast, honestly...between ordering and the first dish showing up, less than 5 minutes passed.)

Why 3 stars? Because it's really too loud in there. Why do restaurants not invest in acoustic ceiling panels by default? The moment they add some sound-dampening, this will be a 5 star review, but otherwise, I will only order take-out. It's louder than any restaurant I've ever been in, and louder than the bar I went to after.
author: Eric H.

description:
I'm new to SF, and I've only been to this place for lunch, but I think it is really good, and a really good DEAL!

So you get two options (two dishes!) for the lunch special, which is under ten bucks (I want to say $8.50 or $9?  It's way cheap, yo)  and I've been dabbling in vegetarian/GF, and there are tons of meat-free options -- my go-to is shrimp and veggies with red curry with brown rice.  Try it, you'll love it!  The jasmine iced tea is real good, too.
author: Bobbie J.

description: Their lunch special is bang for your buck. At $9.75 you receive 2 items with rice plus and salad. At first glance the items don't look like a large portion but the plate they're placed on is deceptively large. I chose an eggplant dish and cashew chicken and didn't think there would be so much leftover at the end. While this isn't the most remarkable Thai food I've had, the food is delicious, the establishment is clean and comfortable and the area is great for walking off your meal.
author: Catalina C.

description:
Pros:
- Service
- Food presentation was nice
- Garlic Rice was da bomb..

Cons:
- Price $$
- The food was consistently too spicy and they don't ask you how spicy you want your food.
- The "steamed" chicken had lots of skin, cartilage, and was really greasy, was hoping for healthy and got heart-attack-ee

TLDR: Thai food doesn't need to be expensive to be good, I'd rather have it tasty and in a to-go box than fancy and too-hot-to-taste-the-flavor
author: Chris S.

description:
Whoooo.

Lips tingling: check
Sweat beading on my forehead: check
Numbness spreading on my tongue: check
Reaching for something to put out the fire: check

No, that's not my reaction at the last Justin Bieber concert. It's what happened after I dug into the Som Tom Koong Yang shredded papaya salad at Lers Ros. I don't think I've ever been to a Thai restaurant that has even approached the level of spiciness I think Thai people are used to, but I think this might have come close. It just creeps up on you. 

This may have been the best Thai meal I've had in the city. I came here for a late dinner, and you know you're in the zone when you get a parking spot right out front. They were very nice about reservations, and good thing we did, because it was still pretty crowded at 9pm on a Sunday night.

The food here is fantastic. We got mostly the standard Thai dishes this time around, but I will not hesitate to come back for the more unique dishes like the garlic frog or the boar meat, or maybe the stir-fried alligator. The prices are very reasonable, and the portions are fair. I doubt you'll leave hungry. 

What we ordered:

1) Beef Pad Prik Thai: Tender pieces of beef prepared with onions and peppers. Very tender, very flavorful. 

2) Moo Phing: Marinated BBQ pork on skewers. Large slices of pork grilled on the skewer with a chili and rice powder sauce. It kind of reminded me of the bright red sweet chinese beef jerky I used to love eating as a kid. Very good. 

3) Pad Thai: Can't seem to enter a Thai restaurant without ordering pad thai. Noodles were very good, and the whole dish was surprisingly delicate compared to the kind of messy versions you get at a lot of other Thai restaurants. Mix in the fresh and crunchy bean sprouts and the dish was a hit. Nice big prawns in it as well. 

4) Som Tom Koong Yang: Shredded papaya salad with grilled prawns. I loved it, but I was this close to asking if they had a glass of milk because it was pretty spicy. I admit my threshold for spicy is not great, but everyone at the table thought it had some real heat. The only kind of puzzling thing about the salad is that it comes with a quarter head of cabbage. Not shredded or anything, it's just sitting there. Am I supposed to eat it? Is it garnish? 

5) Red curry: I found out recently that a lot of Thai restaurants use food coloring or some other mild color additive like spinach juice (green) or paprika (red) for their curries so it won't be as spicy. Not sure if they do here, but I don't really care because it was still pretty good. I really like coconut milk curries, and the red curr fit the bill. Lots of vegetables and chicken, went great with the jasmine rice. 

6) Tofu with chili and green beans: I was a little scared of this dish when it was brought out because I think underneath all the red chili was some green beans and tofu. But surprisingly, it wasn't that spicy. Green beans were bright and succulent, while the fried tofu soaked up the flavor of the chilies. 

Service was very friendly and efficient. The place didn't seem huge, but they use the space well. There's a bar area with a TV, so I guess you can go for a meal at the bar while you're watching the game. That doesn't sound like a bad idea. Probably one of my new favorites in the city.
author: Saunders C.

description: Ordered the Chicken Satay and Yellow Curry lunch special.  Really amazing favors and great presentation.  Thai Iced Tea was fantastic.  Busy during lunch, but the quick service makes it worth the wait.
author: Doug E.

description: Went here for pick up and I checked my bag before I left. They made a mistake. No apologies. Took them 20 min to remake my order (from rolls to tofu). In total, it took them 35 minutes to make 2 appetizers which I feel is is unreasonable especially given that I was one of just people in the restaurant at 3pm on a weekday.
author: Joanna L.

description:
I could never grow tired of this place. Delicious vegetarian choices; and if you want something exotic, it's the place. My favorite has to be the YELLOW CURRY.

The waitresses know the how popular their restaurant is. I have to say, they are sweet, but they rush you out.
author: Mari V.

description: I rarely write reviews, so when I do I generally have a strong opinion.  The people at this restaurant are just stupid.  They accept reservations on their website which says "no reservations before 5pm" thinking a little odd but...we waited until after 5pm last Saturday to make a reservation for dinner.  The reservation was accepted for 6:15 and gave us a confirmation number.  We get to the restaurant, the person checking guests in says he doesn't have our reservation.  We showed him the confirmation number and he said, "I don't have time to look at the online reservations AFTER 5pm".  Are you kidding me!  Needless to say after a small scene we were give a table with many eye rolls and much snippyness - from them not us.  The thing is, the food is not even very good.  The only reason we were going to go was because it is close to the ballet.  This place would not make it if there were any real competition.  Oh, and ask them for anything additional - like a second glass of wine - good luck.  The servers can't remember anything once they leave your table.
author: Brian N.

description: Good food - great location - nice space - excellent service - good prices. All in all, a winner!
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is my favorite Thai food spot in the city. While I've sampled dozens of their menu items, and been satisfied with every one, a few stand out: the veggie spring rolls, tom yum soup, the whole whole fried tilapia in chili sauce (served with the bone still in it), and the the duck red curry. And don't forget to finish the meal with their friend bananas!

By no means do I consider myself an expert on Thai food. But after spending some time in Thailand last year, Lers Ros serves food that tastes more authentic to me than any other Thai restaurant I've been to in SF. In any city for that matter. But because of that, the food is generally more spicy than other Americanized Thai spots, so be wary if don't like it hot! Even if you ask for it mild, be prepared for some serious punch. 

Love this spot, and will keep coming back!
author: Kori M.

description: Would not let us sit where we wanted so we walked out. Would not let 2 people sit at a 4 person table, and they could care less that we weren't happy being squished in between two other tables.
author: Steve D.

description: Woah. Super good. Walked right in on a Friday night with a group of 3 and proceeded to order way too much food as always: papaya salad with prawns, green curry with beef, crispy chicken over ginger rice, and the crispy pork belly. Everything was really good but I couldn't stop eating that crispy chicken. It was incredible. God I wish this place was in my neighborhood.
author: Jessie M.

description: In search of a good restaurant for dinner close to Davies or the Opera House, this small, fairly noisy place definitely hits it.  The dishes pay close pre-ordering examination. Shrimp with asparagus was delicately seasoned (and with ten large shrimp, not stingy); ginger rice with crispy chicken quite Vietnamese in presentation and style; but the beef with chili sauce was some seriously spicy stuff.  And that's what they call "moderate", so be prepared.
author: David B.

description:
I absolutely love eating here!  I could eat here every day of the week...There was actually one week I ate there 3 times!

The decor is very sleek & modern and always seems to have a hipster crowd when I've gone in.  I think if you are wanting to give this location a try on a reasonable expense going at lunch is the best time.  You get to 2 items for less than what one of the items would normally cost you.  So, if you want to experiment, you should definitely go at the lunch hour.  Disclamer: It's not the whole menu that is discounted.  Just some of the more popular items.

I would love to say I've tried something exotic, but I've pretty much stayed to the basics (chicken satay, Kai Himaparn , Kang Karee, and Thai ice tea).  Every single one of those items were delightful & delicious!  One of these days I am going to give the frog, rabbit, or alligator a try...When I do, I'll definitely update this review.

Why ONLY four stars if I like it so much?  The noise level in here can get so darn loud, just hearing the person sitting across from you can be challenging.  Another reason is because it is really a place that comfortably fits you and one other person.  If there are more than 2 of you, you are going to have to spread out awkwardly and there is a high possibility you won't even be seated together.
author: Eboniña E.

description: If you crave novelty (frog legs anyone?) or have a bunch of picky eaters who demand an extensive menu, go to Lers Ros. But if you're looking for great Thai food and decent service, you can find much better in the city and even in Hayes Valley itself.
author: Amy Z.

description:
This used to be my favorite Thai food in the city, until last night when I was blatantly lied to.

I called the restaurant and placed an order for delivery, which I have done countless times before. I gave them my credit card information, and was told it'd be here in one hour. Cut to 50 minutes later. I receive a phone call telling me that I'm out of their delivery zone. Confused, I confirm that it's the same location that I had always ordered from. It was. I ask what their delivery radius is, and they tell me 2 miles. I ask how far away I am, and they tell me I'm 2.3 miles away. I quickly Google Map my distance to cross-check, and low-and-behold, I am 1.9 miles away any way you slice it. I confront the woman on the phone, who counters back, "Sorry my phone tells me that you're 3.5 miles away." What?! She just told me 2.3, where are these numbers coming from? I let her know that I've ordered from them many times, and she tells me that I haven't and I'm not in their system. Not true. When I ask for a manager, the woman on the phone tells me that there is no one else working tonight. Ummmm.

If you really don't want to deliver food that night, just tell me that you're not accepting delivery orders at the moment. No need to lie about multiple things. I'm so disappointed by the lack of professionalism.
author: Dan L.

description:
An old friend and I tried Lers Ros Thai as it was about halfway between us. Good choice. She had a red veggie curry, I a tofu in chili paste with green beans. Both "medium" dishes had just the right kick, at the back of the throat where Thai food usually gets me. I also had a glass of a Portuguese wine from the Dão region that was as fruity and peppery as any I remember from Lisbon. 

Service was excellent, without being overbearing. The servers were attentive and quick. Our food came scarcely five minutes after ordering.

Our only complaint was about the noise. The room has tile floors, marble walls, and high ceilings, so normal conversation was impossible. Even after the place cleared out halfway, we still had trouble hearing each other.
author: David B.

description:
Amazing food and friendly staff.  Our waiter even surprised us with a birthday treat because she overheard that it was our friend's birthday!  I recommend the crispy tofu with chili paste and green beans, the red curry, and prawns with basil and chili sauce.  

Delivery orders can be a little tricky and delivery time can go over an hour on a busy night.  BUT...at least they deliver!
author: Tina L.

description:
Good Thai is hard to find in the Bay Area and this place was recommended to me by a friend but I wasn't blown away and I didn't leave sweating. Granted I lived in Asia for three years and traveled to Thailand often so I know what I like in regards to Thai food but I know SF is not Thailand, so I have to be realistic. 

The Green Curry was fantastic but I found the red curry quite bland. The Green Beans with Spicy Pork was anything but however the Tom Ka Khai Soup was surprisingly robust with it's flavors. As you can see it was a bit of an inconsistent night in regards to flavor and spice levels. However, the staff was uber-friendly, meals came fast and piping hot, wine was flowing and the Som Tom Koong Yang (Papaya Chili Salad) was exceptionally spicy hot - win!

I will give it another go as I have had multiple more recommendations for the place since my visit and I do love me some Thai food but in regards to flavors, my first visit there was good... not great.
author: G C.

description:
Great little Thai place in Hayes Valley.  We've dined in and ordered out multiple times and usually been very satisfied.  Serving sizes are generous and unless you're feeling like a real fat kid, your dinner will always double as lunch leftovers.  

My girlfriend loves the yellow curry and I'm a fan of the green, both with either chicken or beef.  I'd stay away from the Pad See Ew though.  Maybe I hit it on an off-night but the noodles were overcooked and super mushy.  Since then I've stayed with curry and haven't been disappointed.

Only other complaint is that although the service is great and the women are hustling, I've had a few requests that were lost in translation (5 orders of brown rice on 2 entrees).  No biggie, we're local to the hood and will be back often.
author: Rich L.

description:
Poor service and felt rushed.  

Dined here with 3 friends on a Friday night with a reservation.  Ordered and everything seemed ok.  During our soup and salad, waitress basically took the small plate for my friend while she was still holding her fork and has food on it.  Didn't even ask her if she was finished.
Later when we were slowly finishing up, multiple waitresses came by asking if they could clear our dishes.  We obviously weren't looking for our bill so why keep asking us?  Finally after many tries, one of them just brought us our bill, didn't even ask if we were ready for it or wanted dessert.  Of course we didn't want dessert due to feeling like we were being kicked away.  Worst service ever!!!!
author: Debbie H.

description:
I got three words for this place: Tom Kha Kai!!

I LOVE this soup and can't get enough of it. 

The service is good and all the other food is decent as well.
author: Angelica V.

description:
Ended up here after failed attempts at Rebel and Patxis on Easter Sunday so by the time we received our food I was about to pass out, but even if I weren't so hungry I think I'd still say this food was pretty tasty. Yes, it's a little pricey for Thai, but given the neighborhood and atmosphere it wasn't too horrible and the servers were very attentive always asking sure our waters were filled to the brim (we had plenty of Easter wine so we badly needed water).

Now be careful with your requests for "spicy" because you will get it! Even our mild dishes had more heat than expected but I liked it. We ordered the duck curry (red) and chicken pad kee mow with spring rolls and tom yum soup to start and everything tasted great. We didn't order drinks but we got out of there for about $20 a person (we shared the starters across 7 people). If I were in the neighborhood and in need of Thai I'd give it another go.
author: Krystle S.

description: An absolutely superb meal! I loved the Tom Kha Gai soup! It was fantastic. Service was fast, friendly and efficient!
author: Daniel C.

description: Pretty good place to grab lunch while you're in the area. I had the Pad Kee Mow with some lemon ice tea. Service was prompt and attentive.
author: Sidhu H.

description: Very good, quite authenic Thai food. Service good and price reasonable. Eat there once every week.
author: Ken V.

description:
I visited this restaurant on Sunday night, and I'm torn on my review rating since in an ideal world I would give 3.5 stars. So, I'll break the typical mathematical rule of rounding up on odd numbers, and stick with a 3 star. 

So, to the real feedback... We made a reservation and arrived with a group of 10. Fortunately, the table was ready when we arrived - we were a few minutes late (whoops). We started the evening off with beer & wine, and was pleased with the size and variety of their menu. A good mix of domestic and imported beers, and local and international wines. Beer was more than reasonably priced - $4, and wine started at $7 a glass. With a few libations under our belt, we moved on to appetizers. We ordered the spring/egg rolls, and chicken satay. The rolls were good, but the chicken satay was just ok. Frankly, it wasn't anything special, but then again, is there ever such a thing as special blow your mind chicken satay? Probably not.

As for the main courses, we shouldn't have ordered nearly as much food as we did. We basically ordered an entree per person, and since our group was female heavy we learned that was too much. I ate primarily the Pad See Ew - beef, which was mediocre. Other entrees in our group were red curry (duck), yellow curry (chicken), pad thai, sesame chicken, stir fries, etc. 

All in all, not a bad experience, but the food was not anything impressive. I do commend their good service and very reasonable pricing (each entree was ~$10-$13).
author: Kevin C.

description: If I could hold on to all 5 stars, I would. This review is only based on costumer service because I didn't even get the opportunity to try the food. I made a reservation for a large group because my parents and uncle are visiting from out of town and this restaurant came up on yelp as being able to accommodate us. When I called to confirm, they told  me they had sent an email and left me a voicemail canceling. I never received either. When trying to work something out with them, the hostess, nor the person she handed me off to was willing to help. I'm now left stranded with not much time before my concert to figure out a place to eat.
author: G S.

description: Don't get delivery from here. The food is great, however tonight (sunday) we ordered food for delivery at 6:54. They said it would take an hour, at 8:20 it hadn't come and I called, they told me it was on it's way. At 8:45 they still weren't here, I called again, they said he was very very close. At 9:30 I called again and she said the driver had left 10 minutes ago. It is almost 10 and we STILL have not gotten our food :(
author: Aly S.

description: So been to their TL location -- great food.  Was looking forward to the Hayes St experience before the ballet but they gave our table away (we arrived 5 minutes before rez time).  She seemed to think it was okay to ask us to sit at the bar instead.  We left.
author: liz a.

description: I have been here twice and both times the food has been delicious. It's a small restaurant but they get the food out fast and the menu is pretty extensive. I love how the soups come in a pot with fire coming out of it! The mango sticky rice was also amazing. Will definitely be back!
author: Lauren O.

description: The food was beyond lacking and $73 for a tab for 2 for Thai food??? Two main dishes, rice and three drinks total. Don't think so
author: Carolina S.

description:
THIS PLACE FXXKEDUP!!!!
Don't bother dreaming of seated for a table if your party is only 2 or 3.  They HOLD UP ALL TABLES for bigger parties and forced you to sit at the bar, even after you waited for 30+ minutes on the waiting list and your turn is coming up.

My wife and I walked in and signed in the wait list and waited for 30+ minutes.  Then we saw that the customers at a 2-person table about to leave. We checked that we are the next-up table-for-2 party on the waiting list.  When that table is about to ready, we asked and the hostess agreed to let us wait for that table.  Only within 2 minutes 
the hostess said the we cannot have the table, they have to connect it to accommodate a stupid party of 4 that just walked in 5 minutes ago.  They forced us sit at bar. (after waited for 30+ minutes)

Very dissatisfied with the service, treatment and experience received form this restaurant.

I don't care how good their food is, they just don't respect and discriminate against small parties.
author: Fred L.

description: Went here with a party of 12. The menu has all the Thai favorites plus items with frog legs, rabbit and alligator. The pork shoulder appetizer is not to be missed. Garlic frog is a neat hot wings alternative. Spice is well handled without hiding flavors. The wine list is inexpensive. We had 7 apps and eight entres. From them I recommend the pad prig khing as an entree as well as the Green and yellow curries.
author: Michael B.

description:
Loved the atmosphere and that they served a variety of wines!  The pad thai was absolutely amazing.

The service is okay.  They spilled a little of my husband's fish curry on him and didn't apologize or bring him napkins.  Would have given 5 stars if the service was better!
author: Rita W.

description:
Okay, fantastic food, fantastic service, good value, tooooooooo damn loud! 

I mean YOU CAN'T EVEN YELL LOUD ENOUGH TO BE HEAERD ACROSS THE TABLE.  

Can you say "acoustic tiles" ???
author: Christopher F.

description: Duck larb salad was super. Very flavorful with juicy duck and onions wrapped in lettuce. Amazing!! Pad ke mow was also delicious as well as their spicy mince beef dish. Everything errs on the spicy side but everything is well cooked and delicious. The venue is a lot nicer than the one on Larkin. Would come back again!
author: Carrie T.

description: Good thai food. Good prices. Rushed service.
author: Simcha K.

description:
LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD

I came here with the family to eat the same great food served at the original, but with a nicer location. Although, not entirely too far, the difference it makes on the clientele is amazing. This place was packed! It's housed in the same building as Nojo and The Grove. Inside they try to match modern decor in a venue that goes for the hipster bare building look: no drywall and exposed pipes above.

With every table filled, I couldn't hold a conversation with anyone, let alone think to myself. I felt bad for the couple next to us, because it seemed like they were on their first date. Despite the location, the other Lers Ros wins in my mind because the noise level is obnoxiously loud. 

The food is still good no matter where you go.
1. Koh Moo Yang - great way to start. pork shoulder that is crispy smoky and comes with a sauce that blends incredibly well
2. Tom Kha Kai - very cool presentation for a soup. It comes in a donut shaped metal pot with a flame shooting through the middle to keep the soup sizzling hot. This soup is similar to the Tom Yum but with coconut in the broth.
3. Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob - my favorite dish!!!!! crispy skinned pork belly sauteed in their house spicy sauce. Amazing! Get it!
4. Rad Nah - avoid...fat rice noodles drowned in thick soup broth with chicken and some veggies. Pretty forgetable.
5. Pad Kra Prow - very traditional Thai dish that consists of your choice of meat minced and sauteed with their house sauce and thrown on top of rice. Simple, tasty and hard to mess up anywhere.

Next time if I come back here, I'd want to sit at the bar to avoid the craziness.
author: Dennis L.

description:
I always find this restaurent difficult to rate.

I've never had a bad experience here but none of them were exceptional either. I was waiting for it to open for a long time; but my problem is that it's too nice? (the music is absolutely awful though.. god they need to change it asap). 

Their food is pretty decent and are usually known as very authentic thai food. Me for not being thai, I can't say i am impressed with their food. But it can be just me.

However, one should definitely try their pork sparerib dish in the special menu. it's damn good.
author: Sung C.

description:
Came here last minute before a concert nearby.

Lek tom Yum haeng. dry tom yum noodle. yummy had crispy pork belly and fish cake slices in it. YUM! 

Koh moo yang. pork belly wasn't crispy. super spicy sauce. better w/ white rice

great place to go!
author: Judy N.

description:
This place is completely unprofessional. They called me today, less than 3 hours before my reservation to tell me that they could not honor my reservation for a group of 18. The only explanation I got was that the manager said they couldn't do it, even though the table was already set up and I had called the previous day (and the day before that) to confirm because I wanted to make sure that my group of 18 could be accommodated.

Then they proceeded to ask if we could come later.  I asked how much later? The response was, I don't know. Hmm, do you really think I can show up with a group of 18 and wait around indefinitely for a table?  Do you think it's easy to find another place and communicate the change to 18 people in less than 3 hours time?  

I've worked at restaurants before. If a restaurant has a large reservation on the books, the manager knows because he/she has to staff appropriately. I can hardly believe the manager didn't know until 3 hours before the reservation, and if so, they're completely incompetent. Not to mention the manager had someone else call me, they didn't have the balls to call me themselves and apologize for the debacle.

Please just note, this place is not good for groups.  You cannot count on them honoring your reservation, so what is the point?
author: Anna M.

description:
Made it in just before the Valentine's Day rush and it was worth it!  The duck larb, or Larb Phed Yang, (recommended in the BIG EAT SF for 2012 by 7x7 Magazine) was spicy and DELICIOUS.  

I also highly recommend ordering a glass of Riesling to go along with the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (pork belly).  SO GOOD!

A great and trendy date spot.  Do it.
author: Chad S.

description: Lers Ros is a great place to bring a date or a group of friends for a delicious Thai dinner. It can get pretty crowded, so prepare to wait a bit, but for the most part the wait is worth it. The menu is varied and interesting - usually I find two or three things I want to eat just looking at the list of specials! They serve all kinds of meat - even less common things like rabbit, venison, and alligator in addition to Thai staples like chicken, duck, fish, and seafood. The decor is modern and clean; the lighting slightly dimmed to create a nice eating atmosphere. It's pretty lively too because there are quite a few tables packed into a relatively small space. The food is a bit pricey, but it is also distinctive and quite tasty.
author: Alex M.

description:
It's such a nice addition to my work neighborhood.  I remember strolling past many times while they were still in construction...drooling....

My daughter and I visited the day after they opened...it was really yummy, not the typical Thai restaurant faire.  The only thing was I still remember ordering hot water and the water tasted of bleach...

I've returned many many times since that first Saturday...some days their service is horrid...but most days they are lovely...I do have to say that I've received the worst glare for not asking for hot water immediately....one waitress actually tried to talk me into keeping my "not so cold water".....that was unpleasant.  A few times, they've gotten my order incorrectly....but overall, I enjoy their food and most of the time I do receive nice or excellent service...such is life.

We'll be going back.... :)
author: Barb L.

description: Was very good. I had the garlic roasted rabbit. I was nervous to try it but it tasted better than I expected. I have never been here before but would go again soon
author: Mike R.

description:
We had a great dinner at the new Lers Ros outpost last night.  Beautiful room, great service, delicious food, and nice wines.  The food is more expensive than most Bay Area Thai places, but well worth it.  The wine prices are standard -- about $9 for wines by the glass.

We shared 3 dishes: a green papaya salad, vibrant with lime and fish sauce and packing plenty of heat.  They offered it with several optional toppings (crab, prawns, or salted egg) but we went for the plain version.  Next we shared a special "shrimp paste platter" and a dish from the regular menu, Koong Pad Phed (medium shrimp, though they call them "prawns" on the menu, with chili paste, kaffir lime leaves, green peppercorns, and galingal).  The Koong Pad Phed was delicious, but the shrimp paste platter was the hit of the evening.  Lots of broccoli, steamed cabbage, cooked bamboo, cucumber, and squares of an omelet-like egg dish, plus two small whole deep-fried fish, and two raw Thai pea eggplant, served  with a very spicy, pungent dipping sauce.  It was wonderful, and I'd definitely order it again.  

If you don't like spicy food, though, this may not be your place.  Everything was hot-spicy, and the shrimp paste dish made me sweat -- a rarity, even with spicy food.

The dessert menu is short.  I was tempted by the fried banana with ice cream (they had several choices of ice cream flavors), but while our mouths craved something cool and sweet we were too full to tackle it.  Since it was early (this was a pre-concert dinner) we had time to walk a block to Christopher Elbow and get some exquisite chocolates.
author: Robert W.

description: Great food ! Great environment. Not super expensive. Service was fast and efficient. Food was fresh.
author: Elizabeth V.

description:
Food at Lers Ros is always tasty and their new Hayes Valley front is no exception. I've tried a little of everything here from their appetizer satays to their alligator and here are some recommendations for must haves

Pork belly... So yes you need to end this healthy new years resolution bull because this dish so what you really need to change your life!! 

Red curry... Just not a fan of thai eggplant but the dish has great color, super fragrant, and that nice spice that kind of makes you tear for a second and then leaves just as quick. 

Typical pan cooked noodle dishes... Pad thai, pad see ew, and etc.... I don't really dig their special noodle dishes; the best I can describe those are slimy

Lastly, there is a decent wine and beer list. I also received fabulous service but it did border on hovering. 

So why is there a minus 1 star? For a new place I don't dig the decor; its just a too like Osha. Where did the originality go?
author: Joanna L.

description:
We had lunch here this week and it was really tasty. I wish I would have known that it is a 1+ hour lunch experience, because I had an errand to run AND eat lunch. Oh well. 

Kevin and I actually went to city hall to get our DP certificate (so cool/finally!) and then walked over for lunch. 

It gets busy for lunch.. so come before noon.. and expect a whole hour experience (not great if you are rushing). After finally getting to order our food.. and waiting quite a bit for it to come out, we had to ask for the check with lunch.. so that we could jet out after our last bite. 

But, most importantly, the food was very delicious, and I look forward to coming back.. hopefully with more time to spare!
author: Art A.

description:
Food was good, with big portions, but service was lacking.

Got open table reservations for 7:15 on a Tuesday. Started with the garlic quail appetizer and tom kha kai soup (more than big enough to share). The quail was delicious, just hard to eat and pick around the bones (and eat the ones small enough to eat).

For an entree, I had the spicy pork with homemade chili sauce. The flavor was good (not too spicy), and the peppercorn stalks made the dish, allowing me to flavor it with as much fresh peppercorn as I wanted. The wife got a daily special, advertised as a dry tom yum soup. It was great, with a lot of garlic flavor and a variety of ingredients.

The only negative was poor service. We would need to flag down a waiter any time we wanted something. After flagging a waiter to bag the food, we had the bagged food on our table for 10 minutes until we could find someone to ask for a check (no one would check on us, even though we were obviously waiting with a bag of food ready to go). We were planning on getting mango sticky rice but didn't feel like waiting any more. Maybe it was an off night, but other reviews seems to back this trend up...
author: Ned F.

description:
Came here on their first Saturday for my boyfriend's birthday dinner. I had e-mailed in a reservation since no one answered either of the 2 phone numbers provided on their website. Luckily I called earlier that day to make sure because they never received my e-mail. 

The reservation was for 7:15PM and we were seated around 8PM. 

Service: Slow. Might be because it was opening weekend, but they had a lot of waitresses working. We sat at the bar, and even though there were always at least 2 waitresses behind the counter, it was difficult to get any attention at all. However, whenever the waitress was around, she was always extremely friendly.

Food: We ordered the rabbit (chef's special) and shared a beef Pad See-Eu. The Pad See-Eu was good, but not great. The rabbit was not so good. It came with their 'house chili sauce' which tasted like any other sweet and spicy sauce. Rabbit meat must be very lean as well because there was more bone than meat on every piece! Also, they asked if we wanted brown or white rice with the rabbit dish. We chose white rice, but in retrospect, that was not a dish that needed a starchy accompaniment.

Ambiance: Dim lighting, but loud since it's such a small restaurant. People standing inside to wait crowds the bar area a little and makes seating near the door uncomfortable.

Overall it was okay. I mean, given it was their opening weekend, I will assume that they felt the pressure of the highly anticipated grand opening in Hayes Valley. Maybe I'll come back in a few weeks and see how things have changed.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
I've been anticipating the opening of Ler Ros' new location on Hayes for the past few months.. and I'm pleased to report that the food lives up to the high standards set by the original location on Larkin in the Tenderloid.  Let's back up: the Larkin location has been my go-to place for Thai food the past couple of years.  That and Thai House Express (on Geary/Larkin) are the ONLY 2 Thai restaurants I visit on a regular basis.  I grew up in Thailand so I definitely know what is authentic Thai and what isn't and the fact is this:  Ler Ros is the most authentic Thai place in the city.

You can't go wrong with anything on the menu, but my recommendations for a first-timer include the Tom Kha soup, the moo ping pork skewers, the som tum with salted egg and the pork leg stew.

I would have liked to give this new location 5 stars but 2 things are slight negatives:  1) the prices are about $0.50-$1.00 higher than the Tenderloin location and 2) the service was slow.  They are likely still working out the opening week kinks.

I will likely continue to visit both locations.
author: Toby C.

description: It's been almost a year comin to this place and every time I go the service is great. Not to mention the food. You have got to try the crispy pork belly. Yumm!!!! It's a cute spot to bring people to eat in Hayes valley and the food comes out pretty quick. Love love love
author: Victor N.

description:
Holy moley that was spicy! I had to shovel extra rice just to combat it.

And for some reason the staff kept trying to take my plates away before I was really finished.  Maybe because my friend and I were the last customers late on a Wednesday night?

Otherwise tasty, and I will go back.
author: Adrianne S.

description: Food was ok, service was good, decor was nice and ambiance was comfortable. n Green papaya salad was tasty with lots of prawns in it.  Chicken satay was ok...had to be sent back to cook a bit more but they took it off my bill which was a nice gesture. The yellow curry my friend ordered looked delicious and she was happy with it although I didnt taste...over all, a nice place.
author: Nilu r.

description: Really modern inside...very different from the Tenderloin location! I thought the food here was delicious. Yes the prices are a little higher, but the food is worth it. Plus, you are in the trendy area of Hayes Valley after instead of the sketchy streets of the TL.  The waitstaff was very friendly and all speak Thai!  PS - they have high chairs if you need them!
author: Natalie S.

description: After reading that several chefs LOVE this place, had to check it out.  After eating here 3 times, it's definitely super fresh ingredients and coolio design, but the dishes themselves aren't necessarily put together that well.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Get the PAPAYA SALAD with PRAWNS - BOMB. The quarter head of raw cabbage on the plate threw me off at first, but it worked well with the spicy salad. (still not sure if it was meant to be eaten though)

The portions here are good. You'll leave satisfied, but not overstuffed.
author: Lynn P.

description:
Welllllll, good, but nothing to scramble back to for another experience.  I like a lively atmosphere, but this place was a disaster in the sound department.  It was way too echoey (is that a word?).

Service was nice and attentive as they always brought us napkins and re-fills of water without even asking, but I didn't like that they asked us to move tables without giving us a reason, until I asked, which was to make room for a bigger party.  I understand the situation, but I'm a little on the fence about being asked to move, when you're in the middle of having a nice conversation with your party.  It would also be nice if they asked your preference in the heat level department, because the heat level in all of our dishes were a little much.

Food was definitely flavorful, but failed slightly in the price to quantity ratio department.  We had the rabbit - tiny pieces of meat and mostly bone, pork spare ribs - wonderful flavor, but miniscule quantities, papaya salad - great flavors, but insanely hot and pad thai - which knew i shouldn't have ordered it, but we were still hungry, and was a little too sweet and oily

I don't know....I think I like the place, but I need to go back at least one more time...maybe.
author: Grape C.

description: Green Curry is on fire (figuratively).  Best Thai and lunch deal in the area.  This ain't your 'white person pad thai adventurous diner' style Thai.  Get the funky stuff!
author: Keith K.

description:
Absolutely the best Thai place I've eaten in CA. The owner and the waitress there are very friendly and nice.  
My favorite dish is 
* Tom-sab soup (pork rib with spicy soup)
* The pork crispy with Chinese broccoli is the bomb too.  
* Clam with spicy basil sauce is a don't miss!!!
* Pork belly with rind - everyones favorite, its just so damn good
* much more that you have to try yourself.

The cool thing, all of friends that I brought to try their food. Everyone loves it and keep going back as they said food here is really authentic compare to other places else.

Love it!!!! can't wait to go back there again.
author: Risa C.

description: This place was horrible. The garlic frog was over-done with oil that probably needed changing. No creativity to the dishes. The hostess is a sloppy control freak. Both pork dishes that we had were of poor quality. The yellow curry chicken was the only dish we could finish.
author: Matt O.

description:
Had dinner on a Wednesday night around 7:30.

Place was 1/3 full, plenty of empty table. Most 2-tops were already seated. The waitress tells us we have to wait 10 minutes. Apparently one of the 2-tops was about to leave. Why we have to wait for a 2-top on a quiet night. Makes no sense.

We get seated and order quickly. Food comes out pretty quickly. Food is average. No better than a cheaper place. Pad Thai is really sweet. Seemed strange.

We finish quickly and as we were about to leave I look around and the restaurant is maybe half full. 

Service was disappointing and food was average. Not worth the price or the service.
author: Ron S.

description: Came here before going to the Opera. The boo and I had a duck appetizer, pad thai and pad kee mao. Loved all dishes. Only strange thing is that they do not add spice to their food. I requested to have my pad thai with "medium spice" and was told that they don't add spice...but they do have a condiments tray with spices to add yourself.
author: Grace R.

description:
Pros: Outstanding food.  The pork belly was out of this world.  Green papaya salad wonderful as well.  

Cons: Made a reservation but was told that reservations are requests, not guaranteed.  I suppose that defeats the purpose of a reservation.  Server took a while to get to our table.

Overall service was a bit of a problem.  But this is relative to American standards of service.  Anyone that has dined outside of the US, understands that servers are not their to ensure you are happy as a clam, and willing to do anything to achieve that.  They are there to get you fed.
author: Marie V.

description: Good Food and Service. Popped in on Saturday night. Ordered way too much food (Seafood Cake, Tom Kha Kai Soup, Beef, BBQ Chicken). Besides the beef being a little too salty, everything was delicious and the service was excellent.
author: Karena H.

description: Their yellow curry is delicious, their green curry is as well but it's pretty spicy. Only problem is they're kinda pricey
author: Julianne P.

description: LOVE.  This is the best Thai food I have had outside of Thailand itself.  We were rushed to vacate when our meal was finished, but it was a very busy Saturday night.  This being said, the food was amazing, most of the staff spoke Thai, and I understand that lunch specials are great, too.  I will definitely be back very soon.
author: Kevin S.

description:
We arrived around 7pm-ish and the tiny restaurant was packed! We only had to wait about 15 minutes for a table, so that was a plus! However, we felt totally out of place- we were wearing our comfy tourtisty clothes- everyone else was older and looked much more dressy. 
The place was super loud! 
The service was decent, but I felt rushed the entire time I was eating.
The Thai tea was pretty good!
I had good ol' chicken pad thai and it was good,but a bit too sweet.
author: Erica G.

description: A great Thai restaurant!  Very modern and the menu for lunch is long and you get two items!  The curry was very flavorful and there was friendly service.  It gets busy for lunch and it appears a lot of people order for pick up.  I would definitely eat here all the time if I lived in SF!
author: Marcia D.

description: This place is awesome. The food is great. Well lit and modern decor. I like the spicy chicken diced, with brown rice and salad. You get two items for lunch for $9.50. That's a great deal and bargain. I will come here again.
author: Kiana D.

description:
This is the best Thai food I have had in years. I understand why it is so hip, crowded, and does such a great take-out business with the locals and business people. The last time I had Thai this good, I was in Palau about 200 miles from Thailand in a restaurant where everybody spoke Thai. 

To those that sniveled, I can't imagine what they expect Thai food to taste like. This is the best! If there is a better place in SF or the Bay Area, please advise me so I can go there!!

We were pleasantly surprised by the reasonable prices. Noise? MUCHO! Service issues? It is crowded, get used to it, or go somewhere else so we can have your table.
author: Rand S.

description:
HORRIBLE

how do they have two locations. 

The food is bland and in a pool of water - no flavor or taste - just horrible

two dishes came out the same - even though they were different.

music too loud

over priced horrible horrible horrible food
author: first l.

description: One of the beat places for Thai food in SF!! The food come sour quickly and it is always tasty. The service I always a bit behind and they tend to move a bit slow but the quality of the food, prices, and general location make this an awesome place! I typically get the Tom Yum noodles, dry. It is super good!!!
author: William N.

description: The place has nice decor, an interesting menu (boar, alligator, frog...), but what we ordered was pretty good, and the servers quick and polite. We particularly liked the beef jerky appetizer!
author: Tarah O.

description: We got tom kha, pad see ew and red curry. They're all very americanized and flavors do not differ from another thai restaurant in the US. The dining experience was just ok, customer service was sparse. Nothing special at all.
author: May G.

description: Yellow curry with chicken plus sticky rice (tiny portion, but super dense) and a Chang beer. A-OK, as Yelp would say.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I can't get enough of this place. I've only dined in a few times, most of the time we order take out and eat it at home. I love their {ROAST DUCK CURRY}  and {CRISPY CHICKEN} but really I don't think I've had a bad meal here. Really excellent Thai food!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Love the lunch combo here! So far I have tried stir fry garlic pork, minced chicken with basil, and spinach in bean sauce! All are delicious. The service was good and food came out fast. Price is not too bad neither - most combos are under 10 dollars. Yum!
author: Qiqi W.

description:
First, the acoustics in this restaurant are terrible.  I could barely hear my boyfriend across the table talking in a relatively loud voice.

The food was sub par.  The pork we ordered was overcooked, and in a syrupy overly sweet sauce.  The pad see ew was alright, but mostly just mushy with a slightly burnt flavor.

 I would not come back here.   There are many other places in Hayes Valley to eat that are considerably better.   We did not enjoy this experience at all.
author: Ashley B.

description: The yellow curry with chicken was savory and we had to order another round for our famished crew. Darker atmosphere but a comfortable setting not too loud for talking with friends. Trendy place in SF that's worth a try especially when hanging with friends.
author: John S.

description: I love this place.. we go here weekly. It's one of the best thai restaurants in SF! Great atmosphere and the wine is delicious. You can tell the word has gotten out cuz they are busier than ever... Very exciting!! I am a huge fan of the thai basil chicken and the cashew nut chicken. Even when you order to go they treat you very nice... great service and delicious food! Definitely look forward to next week..
author: Josh G.

description: Excellent lunch menu, especially on a Monday when everything seems to be closed in the city. Food is tasty, well spiced and good quantities. The brown rice is excellent, nutty, and full of flavor!
author: P G.

description: It's good food.  But geeez why is it ALWAYS a huge ordeal when ordering delivery? I mean I have to repeat myself 3-4 times, I get put on hold then someone else gets on the line requesting the same information--it's real annoying--therefore I limit my delivery from them to like 3 times a year max.  It's much easier dining in the restaurant.
author: James E.

description: I went here for lunch this week.  This was a great spot for a quick but delicious lunch.  The lunch specials are pretty good- you get a salad, rice and to choose 2 dishes from the set menu.  I had the pad see-ew which I really enjoyed and had enough left over for lunch tomorrow.
author: John S.

description: We came here again and it was packed, took a while for us to be seated. Unfortunately I wasn't as impressed by their portion sizes or the flavor in their curry, there are better Thai options though it is still a solid spot if you want a clean sit-down experience, especially for newbies to Thai food.
author: Kit A.

description:
Disappointing at best.

We stopped by for lunch over a holiday weekend, therefore it was a fairly modest crowd dining. The week prior, I had had three excellent Thai meals in the East Bay  and in SF (restaurants and a catered event), but my palate still hungry for those tangy, fresh and crisp favors you'd expect from a good Thai salad, and the satisfying smoothness of the iconic Pad Thai.

Alas, I give a star each for the clean and modern atmosphere, and the beautiful wine list, and walk-in wine cavern I was able to view along the hallway. I have no stars dedicated for the food. The seafood salad, which came with fish balls, prawns, calamari, a quarter of an iceberg lettuce and what seemed like a whole raw sliced onion. The tangy lime dressing was on point, but the calamari and the prawns were chewy (maybe the idea was that they would be cooked using the lime). The killer was the amount of raw onion - usually a quick pickling makes an onion a delight to eat, but these slices were very 'flavor forward' and fairly inedible. I was still looking forward to the pad thai - if there is one dish that should be done right at a Thai establishment, this is it. Sigh, I would have rather chewed on the onions. Sweet, sticky (heavy on the cornstarch?), salmon-orange in color - monotone in flavor - with a sprinkling of the other traditional components. 

Pluses - the staff was friendly.

I had high hopes since I have had great experiences at the sister restaurant on Larkin last year, maybe that's why I'm a tad more critical.
author: Basil B.

description:
A wonderful, quick, local, tasty Thai food!

Service is quick and attentive, now admittedly we arrived before the dinner rush, but still great.  Extensive menu and the food great.  Good spice/heat, great flavors and the variety is wonderful.

Had a variety of curries, starters (including the papaya salad) that included Tom Kar Gai soup, rolls, chicken satays all great.  The one miss was the alligator -- had to try it and the texture/flavor was off but except for that, everything else was great.

Highly recommend it as a wonderful Thai restaurant in SF.  Please note the have two locations so this one is for the Hayes Street one.
author: Joe S.

description: We started with the duck larb- it was the best out the bunch we've ordered. It was really flavorful and the duck was roasted well. It had a good ratio of tender pieces  and crispy portions of duck. We shared one order between two people, but could've easily killed and order for each of us. We liked the Pra ram khai ( chicken breast w/ peanut sauce.) The steam from the spinach that sits underneath the chicken has a tendency to water-down the dish if you let it sit too long. With that said it was tasty- the peanut sauce tasted fresh. It tastes like chicken satay, but stir fried with additional peanut sauce on top. The Koong pad khing ( stir fry prawns with ginger and mushrooms) was ok- the sauce wasn't overwhelming and it didn't have that gelatinous texture that you get with a lot of saucy cheap Asian foods. It did taste fresh but we  were expecting the ginger flavor to be more present. The plus side was the huge prawn. The pad Thai was ok- the portion was huge. Service was great. Definitely coming back when I'm in town.
author: Fred O.

description: Love their Thai food.  Had the coconut soup, duck larb and calamari.  Can't wait to go back.  Delcious.
author: Nora S.

description:
I am a bit of a Thai snob, especially when it comes to Kang Karee - which is my absolute fav.  I have tried a few different versions of it from Boston, to Miami to the Bay.  I am not hesitating to tell you I think Lers Ros Kang Karee is the best I have had.  Maybe it was the rainy day, maybe it was the hunger pangs, maybe revisionist history or a streak of bad yellow curry in AZ but regardless, this was awesome.

I have since tried the Pad Thai and the Rad Nah, which were both ok, but the Kang Karee is the star for me.  Nice atmosphere and friendly staff and at least for me, a great location
author: Jay B.

description: Came here with a few friends on one of their suggestions. We had pork belly with basil and peppers and some other noodly Thai dish. I am never impressed by Thai food for some reason, it is always just okay to me. However, this place had really delicious food. Very fresh tasting, quality ingredients, good presentation and service. They serve some pretty exotic stuff like frog, alligator, and rabbit which is pretty cool if you like to adventure. You can tell the decor was very well thought out, the furniture was modern and stylish but still comfortable. I am a huge fan of the soundproofing pyramids on the ceiling, looks cool and lowered background noise. Parking is okay, food was awesome, would recommend.
author: Alex P.

description: Great great food for reasonable price. Make sure you try one of the curries and the hot-and-sour soup. We loved it
author: Reza F.

description: We've eaten here quite often before. The food is good but obviously they've changed their reservation policy. Last Saturday, when we arrived, we were directed to the bar even though there were 6 empty tables. We noticed another couple come in, who also had reservations, and were also directed towards the bar. Two minutes later, a party of 6 came in and were immediately seated. Apparently, they overbook, and then accommodate the larger parties first. WON'T BE BACK!
author: Jimmy L.

description: Maybe I just don't like Thai food, but this place turns me off.  Tried it four times, and disappointed in each instance.
author: Reza M.

description: Food is good but they don't have it together on the carry out orders. Waited 20 minutes longer than they said and stood at the door. Not a good experience.
author: Lisa B.

description: A real twist to the menu... Frog, Wabbit and Quail! Great service.
author: Madhusudhan R.

description: Slow service on a weekday lunch break, including long wait just to be seated while waitresses just walked by, left a bad taste in my mouth. We also had to wait a long time for our check, which isn't ideal on an hour lunch. The lunch special was decent, there were several vegetarian options. I had the praram and the fried tofu. The peanut sauce on the praram was quite different then I am used to, it wasn't thick or super peanuty. I didn't like that the tofu in the praram was just raw. The fried tofu was excellent however the sweet chili sauce had a bit too much vinegar. Overall it was a decent deal for $9.75. An improvement in service and having some noodle lunch options would go a long way.
author: Cori W.

description: Ok folks- the papaya salad here is outstanding. The medium spicy is extremely spicy- so beware, but if you love spice it's so good. I ordered another after devouring the first one. Perfect amount of acidity from the lime, creaminess from the peanuts, crunch from the papaya, and sweetness from the tomato. Top this off with garlic and spice = yum (I got the vegetarian version). Probably the best papaya salad I've had outside of Thailand; beats Sripraphai in NYC.
author: Pria P.

description: Food 4.5 stars excellent, not dumbed down too much at this location. But..... 2 stars for being   SOOOOOOO LOUDDDDDD!!!!!!! I could not converse with my friends. The Cacophony is terrible..I am not sure what the can do but they better. I will be sticking to the Larkin Street one for now on..
author: Jason C.

description: Better quality of food, ambiance, service than it's sister restaurant on Larkin Street. Please make sure you try their Catfish dish.... so tender and it just melts in your mouth. Heaven!!!
author: Reyner T.

description: After reading the reviews I wasn't sure rather I should walk in it not but the food was great. Loved the pad thai! The service surprisingly for a thai plane was awesome. I highly recommend
author: Chad P.

description: The food is good and if you get their lunch combo it's a great deal, but the interior is really nice too. They have a bar area where you can sit at lunch if it gets busy, pretty convenient.
author: a f.

description: The one on Larkin is better (particularly noticeable on the pork belly, it seems very overcooked here), but this one is much nicer and in a better area. If I were with friends or on my own, I'd definitely go to the one on Larkin. If I were on a first date, I'd much prefer this spot. On the whole, still quite tasty and reasonably priced.
author: David C.

description:
Had a reservation for 6 people at 8. Wasn't seated until 8:45. Totally unacceptable wait time.  Were I with a smaller group, I'd have left as soon as they told me there was a '15 minute wait' for a table. 

As for the food, it was above average quality for Thai and I did enjoy the meal. Service was good after we made a request to be out by a certain time (on account of the lateness) and we didn't have any rude service or similar once we were seated, as others appeared to.
author: Rob C.

description: We came here just for dessert and got the fried banana with toasted almond ice cream. It was amazing. The ice cream was by the far the best I've ever had.
author: Kristin R.

description: This place was recently closed by the Health Dept. Why isn't that info on Yelp's review of this restaurant? I thought you were going to post Health Dept. scores/actions?
author: Mike F.

description: My coworkers and I (Melissa D. & Kevin N.) have been anticipating the opening of Lers Ros.  They've tried the one in the TL and wanted to compare the dishes to the new Hayes Valley location.  Clean. Modern.  The restaurant has been packed out the door all week.  We lucked out and got the last table for the 1pm lunch crowd. There was about a 10-15 minute wait before we were able to order but once we did, the food came out in minutes.  I had the vegetarian pad thai while the others had the $9.75 two item combo with rice.  I'l be back to try the extensive selection of vegetarian options.
author: Stacey L.

description: A good addition to the neighborhood.  I live very close to this place and have gone there a few times.  It's very efficient there -- always looks busy but there always seems to be a table available when I've come in.  The food is good, service is pretty good (only the last time there was a snafu with our server who was upset that she got our appetizer order wrong, seemed to want to blame us, but got over it eventually and all was well by the end of the meal).  I like that this place is an option here, as there don't seem to be many other Thai places nearby.  I'll keep coming back, as a resident of the neighborhood and even after I move away if I'm going to a symphony or opera for a nice, quick meal.
author: Andrea T.

description:
my fav. spot in Hayes Valley (after Hayes and Kebab) - worst place- LIVEFIT... and no it's not cuz i'm fat! 

Great Thai Place!!!!
author: Ryan M.

description:
Tentative 5 star, might change upon further review.

Came here for a super quick lunch one afternoon. I had about 30 minutes to spare. Walked in and asked if it would be possible for me to get a rushed order since I needed to be out of there quick. The hostess reassured me and showed me to my seat. I ordered the lunch special with veggie green curry and pad kra pao gai. I walked in at exactly noon, it took me about 5 minutes to look at my menu and order, and I kid you not, at around 12:10pm, I had my steaming fresh food right in front of me. I'm assuming this was made possible because they have large quantities of the lunch specials available at the ready for the lunch crowd, but man I was amazed. The food was really good too! It came with a tiny iceberg lettuce salad with some slightly oversweet dressing. The green curry was on par with some of my favorite green curries and had just the right amount of spice to it. They used a green, striped eggplant for it which was interesting. It was slightly undercooked but I'm not gonna give them a hard time for that when they got me my food in 5 minutes. The chicken was flavorful and moist, which went great with the rice. All for about $9.75 or so. Slightly expensive but still good quality. I was out the door by 12:30. Great service, and I would definitely come back again.
author: Sannie L.

description: If you like spicy food like I do this is your spot. Great lunch specials pick 2 and add some brown rice for a few cents more and wash it down with a Anchor.
author: Chris D.

description: I like the food, but I had a really bad experience last time I ordered in. The lady who was delivering the food tried to short-change (!) me on my money after she complained that I didn't give her enough tip. Last time I checked, it's up to the customer how much he wants to tip and 15% is pretty decent. I'll certainly think twice before I order food there again :-/
author: Christian O.

description: Pad se lew and pad thai entrees were delicious and great customer service.
author: Trifecter H.

description:
I love this place. I'm not Thai or Asian, but I think this is one of the best Thai restaurants in the city. Also, I love spicy food, and their food is really spicy when they say spicy (probably the only place I've ever been in the US that is legitimately spicy when they say spicy).

This has become a go-to place, highly recommend it both for the food and the service.

Parking is the only problem.
author: Ron A.

description: Good Thai food & very authentic, prawns & asparagus are yummy
author: K B.

description:
Bottom line - unless you are a masochist and enjoy being treated like sh*t by restaurant staff - do yourself a favor & pass on Lers Ros!  If I could give it negative stars I would - absolutely the worst experience I have ever had (and thus my first yelp review).  

Called in Friday to make a Saturday 6PM reservation.  I TRIPLE checked with the man I spoke to confirming the date, time & that this was for the Hayes location.  We show up on Saturday & were met by the rudest "hostess" ever.  The minute I told her I had a 6PM reservation - she informed me that no I did not & I must've called the wrong location WITHOUT EVEN LOOKING AT HER RESERVATION LIST.  When I explained that this was not the case she then demanded to see my cell phone to prove to her that I had called the right location - WTF??!!  There was another party standing by that had EXACTLY the same issue & got the exact same response.  The "hostess" then proceeded to literally walk away from both said parties in the middle of trying to sort this out and seated walk-ins that came in after us.  She then disappeared into the kitchen - refusing to even acknowledge us.  It was unbelievable.  I realize they can keep their restaurant full in spite of this horrendous "customer service"  (and even, apparently, a recent shut down for roaches and improper hygeine which I somehow missed in reading other reviews) but it's no way to run a business. Do yourself a favor & enjoy one of the many other fine offerings in the area who know how to treat customers with COMMON DECENCY & will appreciate your patronage.
author: Holly C.

description:
one of my favorite restaurants of all time in the bay area has finally moved to a nicer location, with more upscale silverware, different ambient music, and the same menu of hits (except un-numbered).  had the Kua Tiew Rua (beef boat noodle), still great with a complex aromatic broth this time more spicy than tangy, and perfectly cooked soft beef pieces.  also had the Yum Koh Moo Yang (roasted pork shoulder salad), spicy, with the perfect soft flavorful marinated pork shoulder and chili rice powder, parsley, onion, etc.  prices are higher, for example now the fish i like is $15
if eating vegetarian, easy to get pad kee mao, and papaya salad.
also tried the garlic shrimps which were ok.
so they have a new specials menu.  also the prices are still higher
crispy pork belly rind a bit chewy.
author: Rob C.

description: For the food, I give it a 5. I highly recommend the duck larb. It is AMAZING!!!  It's a bit spicy and I love spicy food,  but if ur a little weak then ask then to take it down a notch.   I have only been in San Fran for a few months, and this is by far my favorite Thai restaurant here. The service is great, almost a little too much at times though because they work as a team, so you have too many people checking on you at times.  The only reason I am giving it a 4 is for the sound.  They need to do something to better absorb the sound.  I have been enough times now though that I know to sit on the bar side.  It's a little quieter on that side.   I will be back again and again.  This place is great!!!
author: Coraly S.

description: The food is OK but it took an hour and a half to get food delivered and I live less than 5 minutes away from the restaurant.  So be aware...
author: Laura S.

description: 5 starts for the vegetarian papaya salad, wine list, and updated location; 3 stars for the rest of the food (both the green curry with tofu and the pad see-ew were fine, but nothing to write home about) and for the service (they kept whisking one party's dishes away before both of us were done; they dropped the check when we were halfway through our bottle of wine and then tried to pick it up to run it until i hid it).  I guess that averages out to 4 stars, but I'd rather have take-out from Osha.   I'll probably be back to try other dishes, because friends rave about their TL location and the Hayes Valley spot is just too convenient *not* to go back to; but I'm not expecting greatness.
author: Nori H.

description:
The restaurant is nicely designed and modern looking.  The food is good and fairly priced for the serving size. I had heard good reviews of their other restaurant and was really looking forward to this dinner.
